name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The final draft agenda of this part-session, as set out in the Conference of Presidents at its meeting on Wednesday 13 May 2015 in accordance with Rule 149 of the Rules of Procedure, has been distributed.  In agreement with the political groups, I propose first of all that the vote on the reports of the joint debate on the common security and defence policy be postponed until voting time on Thursday and that the vote on the Commission's delegated regulation on ethyl alcohol of agricultural origin be brought forward to Wednesday's vote. So: safety on Thursday, ethyl alcohol on Wednesday. I see overwhelming support.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: – Mr President, I would just like to inform you that, last Friday night, President Porochenko signed a legislative package prohibiting the use of communist symbols and the communist name in his country. What I want to ask you is whether you do not consider this to be a restriction on democratic freedoms and what do you intend to do?

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking because the Italian newspapers this morning are telling a very serious story: in Budapest since Last July there has been a 33-year-old boy living under threat of death, a death threat because he is a gay activist. There are former Members of the Jobbik Party who are constantly threatening him; A eur 10 000 bounty has been put on his life on the websites of that country. Yesterday, Mr President, we celebrated World Day to Combat Homophobia against Transphobia. It is intolerable that in a European country there should be a death threat to a boy's life simply because he is a gay activist.  Next July there will be pride: I call on you, Mr President, and all my fellow Members to go to Budapest and take part in condemning these threats which are intolerable in our Europe.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Thank you, Mr Viotti. However, this has nothing to do with today's agenda. With the final draft agenda I mentioned earlier, the following amendments have been requested: Monday: no amendments. Tuesday: The Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance and the S&D Group request that a resolution conclude the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the situation in Hungary. The Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance is also asking for a roll-call vote on this. First of all, Mrs Harms has the floor to explain her reasoning.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Indeed, during the last part-session, when Viktor Orban's move in favour of the death penalty in Hungary became known and when a questionnaire was distributed in which the refugee policy in Hungary was to be clarified by means of a referendum, my group had already said that we should agree on a debate and a resolution. That is why, because of the worsening situation in Hungary, we are calling for a resolution to be debated and adopted in this Plenary.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, I do not need to argue much more about the desirability of a resolution because I share basically what has already been raised by Mrs Rebecca Harms. The point is that my group would like this resolution to have time to mature after the debate we are going to have tomorrow afternoon and we would therefore prefer the resolution to be put to a vote in June. Therefore, yes to a resolution, preferably in June.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Before I put these amendments up for discussion and vote, I would like to give you the following proceduralally. The Latvian Presidency, in a letter dated 14 May, let me know that it does not wish to take part in this debate because of the Council's lack of positioning. At the same time, I have received a letter from the Prime Minister, Mr Orban, asking for participation in the debate here. First of all, I would like to inform you purely procedurally that I am not aware of any case in which the Presidency-in-Office of the Council refuses to take part in a parliamentary debate on the grounds that there is no position of the Council. (Applause) We would have to say, for a large number of legislative procedures, that the Council would then have to be on permanent leave. That cannot be an argument. I will, of course, be invited to this House if he so wishes, Prime Minister Orban. Since I have been President here, I have complied with the rule that members of the European Council can, of course, visit the European Parliament and take their position here if they so wish. I even think that this is the place where European policy is to be made public. That is the European Parliament here! That is why I intend to comply with Mr Orban's wish. What is not possible, however, is for Mr Orban to assume the role of presidency. In this respect, we must establish a procedural procedure. I have therefore asked the group chairmen of all the political groups to come to my office shortly after this opening, so that we can clarify the question of how we deal with the issue procedurally tomorrow. You have heard Mrs Harms and Mr Guerrero explain the two amendments. Does anyone want to speak in favour of the motion tabled by the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance?

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Mr President, my Group would support the proposal from the Greens, and we would also support that a resolution be taken in May. What you have just said only underlines the urgency for Parliament to express itself on this matter and we should not wait. My Group will wholeheartedly support the proposal.

name: József SZÁJER
text: – Mr President, I think the procedure which is going on here, whereby someone in one of the Member States who does not belong to a majority party here in the European Parliament says something and we call an emergency debate and resolution, is not the right way. Rebecca Harms gave two reasons why we should have a resolution on this, and both of them are false. The first was on the death penalty. Viktor Orbán made it clear, in conversation with the President and also in public statements, that he is not taking any measures to reintroduce the death penalty. So there is nothing on the table. The other issue is whether there will be a referendum in Hungary. There is not going to be a referendum in Hungary. Rebecca Harms, when asking for a resolution on this question, should have been better prepared on this, because this is not a referendum but a questionnaire with about a dozen questions on immigration, which is currently the hot topic in Europe. They do not like these questions being asked of the people. I think that the two reasons given by Rebecca Harms are false, so my opinion is that we should not have a resolution on this topic.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I have yet to confirm this for the sake of correctness. I would have added that now, Mr Szajer, but you have come before me. I announced at the last plenary session that I would be calling Mr Orban. That is what I did. I had a long phone call with him. In that telephone call, he said exactly what Mr Szajer has just said, namely that his government has no intention of taking any legislative measures to introduce the death penalty. Incidentally, I also published this in a press release in consultation with him. (Parliament accepted the S&D Group's request)

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Mr President, I would like to go back to what you have told us about the Council's presence because it is not a first. Indeed, you should know that the Latvian Presidency has had the same attitude several times in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Therefore, I think that this is a global problem that needs to be dealt with properly because the Council does not respect the functioning of the European institutions. I think this problem is very serious and I wanted to re-establish it on this point.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I believe that I have made my position on the Council's behaviour quite clear here. Wednesday: No changes. Thursday: The S&D Group requests that the debate on cases of violations of human rights, democracy and the rule of law be put to the vote in the morning and the resolutions concluding these debates at 12 noon.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, my group would generally like the urgents debates to take place on Thursday morning, in order to highlight the importance that the issues we are discussing really have, which often save human lives. This is a general position. At the moment, what I are asking is that, for this House, matters relating to emergencies should be discussed in the morning and voted on at noon.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, I do not agree at all with the idea of moving emergencies in the morning for two reasons. First, we can work very well on Thursday afternoons. I don't see why we would only work three days and not four full days. Secondly, in this Parliament, the tradition is that emergencies are dealt with in the afternoon. I would point out that when emergencies are treated in the afternoon, there are more people than when they are scheduled in the morning. I am therefore quite against the proposal that was made earlier.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Cora van Nieuwenhuizen on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on indices, used as a benchmark for financial instruments and financial contracts (COM(2013)0641 - C7-0301/2013 - 2013/0314 (COD)) (A8-0131/2015).

name: Cora van NIEUWENHUIZEN
text: Rapporteur. Tomorrow we will vote on crucial legislation: the regulation on benchmarks used in financial instruments and financial contracts. The last few months have been hit again. Investigations, billions in fines, headlines about cheating and scams in the financial sector. The reason this time: fiddling with the 4pm fix benchmark, a benchmark price on which exchange rates of all major currencies are based. And the LIBOR scandal also brought a new record fine, this time for Deutsche Bank. The myth that benchmark fraud is the work of some bad apples within a few banks has now been definitively broken. Manipulation has occurred in many sectors, including large and important benchmarks. All this demonstrates the importance of benchmark indexes for financial stability and also the need for proper regulation to prevent manipulation of these types of systemically important benchmarks in the future. The legislation we are voting on tomorrow is aimed at protecting the stability of the financial system and the real economy. This means that there must be sufficient safeguards for large benchmarks such as LIBOR or the currency exchange benchmarks that we all use on a daily basis. But the regulations must also ensure that a large and diverse range of indexes remains possible, both inside and outside Europe. After all, a large offer allows investors to switch and switch to other benchmarks. Without alternatives, more and more instruments and contracts will be linked to an ever-shrinking group of indexes, resulting in greater market concentration, more power for the producers of the major indexes and, of course, greater risks to the financial system and the economy. Competition in the benchmark industry creates innovation, reduces systemic risks and strengthens market discipline. This means that for smaller benchmarks there must be a balanced treatment in the regulations. The report, as it stands, provides that balance, a balance between large and small benchmarks, between financial and commodity benchmarks, and between those benchmarks produced in the EU and beyond. This balance sheet is sorely needed to protect consumers, to grow capital markets, to promote economic recovery and also to achieve the vision and objectives for a European Capital Markets Union. I think it is also for this reason that the legislative text received the support of the Committee on Economic Affairs by a majority of 48 votes in favour and only 10 against. Fortunately, that support came from parties on both the left and the right. I would like to thank my fellow negotiators, the shadow rapporteurs, very much for the collegial and constructive way in which they have contributed to the drafting of the report. I am very much looking forward to continuing this cooperation in a good way during the trialogues. I call on all the political groups to support this report so that we can quickly and with a strong mandate that we can enter into those trialogues, so that, after almost two years of discussion, we can actually bring good legislation on benchmarks into force at the end of this year.

name: Nathan GILL
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, benchmarks may sound like a minor technical issue, but in fact they go to the heart of the financial services sector and to the economy more widely. They are the basis on which financial contracts are priced. They determine the value of great numbers of financial products, including the interest rates paid on many mortgages. The investment and pension funds in which citizens save for their future use benchmarks to determine their value or their performance. So it follows that we need to be able to trust benchmarks, but a sequence of scandals has badly undermined confidence – and let us not forget that this is not a victimless crime. For me, manipulating benchmarks is the same as stealing. So that is why, to rebuild trust, we proposed that benchmark providers should be properly regulated and supervised; that they should put governance controls in place and manage conflicts of interest; that they should make benchmark setting more transparent and ensure that contributors to benchmark setting are appropriately overseen.  For critical benchmarks with cross-border impacts, we also propose setting up colleges of national supervisors, involving the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA). This will ensure appropriate oversight and the continuous availability of these benchmarks by requiring contributions from firms if needed.  This has not been an easy file, but it is a critical one, and I would very much like to congratulate Ms van Nieuwenhuizen on the skill with which she has taken it forward. I look forward to discussing some issues further in trilogue. The broad scope of the legislation means that it needs to be appropriate both for big and for small benchmarks, and although our proposal had elements of proportionality, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Control has proposed a more risk-based approach for non-critical benchmarks. I am grateful for your thinking on this and look forward to helping to strike the right balance.  As the EU will be the first jurisdiction to establish such a wide-ranging benchmark regulation, we must also address the question of access for third-country benchmarks, and while we want to keep our borders open, we must avoid importing risks linked to benchmarks that are not robust. Here again I look forward to discussing how we can achieve those objectives. Overall, I think that this is another important step in making sure that we have the building blocks for a strong financial system in place. Now we need to put these measures into effect.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Foreign Trade, Research and Energy. – Mr President, the vast majority of European citizens are affected, directly or indirectly, by benchmarks. Currently, we have different suppliers producing different benchmarks, using different methodologies. Many of the benchmarks have in fact become public goods. As such, its social benefits should be maximised, while the damage caused to the real economy and society as a whole, resulting from its potential poor production or manipulation, should be placed under close scrutiny and subject to criminal and pecuniary sanctions. My opinion focused mainly on commodity price assessments provided by supervisory agencies and physical energy markets. The current provisions prohibiting the manipulation of the benchmarks used do not address all vulnerabilities verified in the production process. Price valuation models vary considerably. We also know that manipulating commodity price valuations can put at risk not only the investor but also the end-user, as this is what determines the price that many households will pay for gas or any other energy supply. Furthermore, we cannot ignore conflicts of interest or agency, which is the case when there is no proper governance and controls. I therefore welcome the legislative initiative in this regard, as self-regulation has proved inefficient.  In my opinion, I tried to minimize the vulnerability of the evaluation process, facilitate the determination of the price evaluated, whether it accurately reflects the transactions of the physical market you want to measure, whether the data are sufficient to represent that market and whether they are in good faith. I have sought to facilitate the ability to detect, deter and, if necessary, take coercive measures in relation to manipulation or other abusive conduct. My final assessment is, however, negative in view of the proposals we have discussed here, not only because my proposals have not been accepted but because the essential issue, that of critical benchmarks, has fallen far short of what it should be. The final wording is very limited with regard to proportionality and with regard to the definition of what is a critical benchmark or a critical benchmark.  I proposed to extend the scope of what is considered a critical benchmark, there were proposals from the Green and Socialist groups, which would be essential to ensure effective regulation of this matter, but all this was refused.  So, finally, in an area as sensitive as this, it's critical to do it, rather than pretending to do it. Unfortunately, little is done and this is not enough for us to be rested or to restore confidence.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: , on behalf of the EPP Group. – Mr President, it was said quite clearly by the rapporteur, Ms Cora van Nieuwenhuizen, and by Commissioner Lord Hill that the situation in the past was bad and could have far-reaching consequences for the credibility of the financial market and stability of the economy.  We should say here that many steps were taken in order to make the financial indices that are of vital importance for financial markets more robust. Now we are debating what is probably the last step in the creation of a safer environment that will bring credible and robust financial industries: legislation that is focused on administration of benchmarks and the creation of the indices. As was said by the rapporteur, the proposal was put together quite some time ago and unfortunately it was not approved by the previous Parliament. The reasons were also quite technical. The Commission opted for a very wide and very deep proposal which drives concern for the sustainability of this regulation, especially for small indices. There were many questions concerning the consistency of this regulation with the international environment, which went rather towards the recommendation issued by IOSCO, and obviously it created problems with the third-country regime. I am very happy that I could work on the legislation with the rapporteur because she opted for a balanced approach, focusing on better proportionality between the regulation of important – the most important – indices by allowing transparency to be used for improving the quality of the other indices. At the same time, we improved too the situation vis-à-vis the third-country regime and found the right balance between the responsibility of national supervisors and the responsibility of ESMA.  I feel we have a very good proposal in front of us. I hope that Parliament will give a strong mandate for us to negotiate in trilogue as there is a difference between the opinions of Parliament and the Commission, and that we will end up with a very good regulation that will fulfil all expectations.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs who have been negotiating this Regulation in recent months, which I believe will substantially improve the Commission's initial proposal.  The position of my group , of the Socialist Group – has been focused on improving the control and regulation of critical indices and, in this regard, in the text being put to the vote tomorrow we have achieved a definition of a qualitative critical index which allows the definition of national critical indices. Further, to the extent that these critical indices are a 'public good', as our colleague Matias said, they will be able to be subject to a reasonable price controlled by the supervisor and, moreover, those critical indices will have a college of competent authorities chaired by ESMA thanks to the text to be adopted by this Parliament.  We are therefore very pleased with the regulation we have achieved so that critical indices (the Eurobor, LIBOR — the large indices that jeopardize financial stability) can be subject to stricter regulation and that, moreover, commodity indices can also be defined as critical. In return, it is true that the negotiation has been complicated and we have had to give in in some respects. That proportionality which the rapporteur was talking about and those who preceded me in the use of the word implies that non-critical indices are going to have somewhat less restrictive regulation. But it is true that, thanks to our group, national competent authorities will have the control power to monitor how the administrators of these non-critical indexes do their job with further analysis in the reports of how these indices are developed.  Finally, we have reached an agreement to ensure that third-country indices comply with IUCV rules. It's something else than there was before, it's not all we would have liked, but we think it's a great deal that's going to allow consumers, European citizens, to have much more robust and much more serious rates.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: , on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for all her hard work in putting forward a sensible approach to this file and accommodating so many political groups in the compromise position we are voting on tomorrow.  This text provides a good framework for national competent authorities to supervise benchmark administrators within a sound European framework. This new regime will ensure that investors and consumers are protected across the entire EU. The approach rightly focuses a tough regime upon critical benchmarks and is not overly onerous upon other benchmarks that are easily substitutable. The focus upon transparency to users of benchmarks will allow investors and consumers to decide if they are happy with the way in which benchmarks are compiled and use alternatives should they find it necessary. The more proportionate approach taken within Parliament’s text for non-critical benchmarks is to be welcomed. However, it is only possible if Member States are also able to choose to elevate a benchmark that may not naturally fall into the critical category, should they feel it is systemically important to their domestic market; indeed they should be able to upgrade to critical status if they think that index is particularly susceptible to manipulation.  As we begin negotiations with the Council and the Commission, I would urge all parties to pay particular attention to the way our third-country provisions interact, with a proportionate approach being proposed for non-critical benchmarks. The use of internationally—agreed IOSCO principles to measure equivalence is of fundamental importance to improving the standards that benchmark administrators globally are held to, without creating the many problems we have seen with other pieces of legislation that have had an extra—territorial effect.  I look forward to working with the rapporteur and the rest of the negotiating team in trilogue to achieve a workable and beneficial outcome for all.

name: Sylvie GOULARD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, thank you for being with us. I would also like to thank Cora van Nieuwenhuizen, even though she is part of the ALDE group, because, at least in the name of priority, those who were present during the previous mandate know how difficult the issue was.  Commissioner, I very much appreciated your strong words. I hope they will guide you through the trilogue and that, when you are dealing, perhaps - who knows? To somewhat reluctant states, you will use the same kind of words in front of them. I believe that Cora van Nieuwenhuizen has achieved a balanced result with great work also from other political groups. This is worth noting.  On the other hand, personally, I would have preferred an even more determined role for ESMA. This supervisory authority has been created so that, precisely, in the internal market, it is not possible to evade. So in defining the many technical standards, ESMA will have a role, that's true. This institution will also have a role as the ultimate arbiter for the definition of critical indices , I think this is a very crucial point - namely all indices that are not linked to an exchange rate or interbank but which have an impact on financial stability. The management and monitoring of the public register of reference indices is also entrusted to it, and ESMA will have a role in the event of non-compliance with the rules by a competent authority. I think this is going really in the right direction.  Commissioner, I draw attention to the issue of Esma's budget, which is still, like that of all these supervisory authorities, a little threatened at all times. If the Council were there, I would also say it to the Council. There will be a difficult balance to be struck between supervision and close supervision given the influence of certain indices and proportionality given the number of indices. It will therefore be gradually in the implementation that, in my opinion, we can, in a pragmatic way, possibly rectify the situation. In any case, thank you all and good luck for the trilogues.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Mr Hill, you mentioned that manipulating amounts to stealing. I would like to talk to you about the IRPH and this Regulation, which is supposed to be born precisely with the specific objective of reducing the risk of manipulation of benchmarks. However, the minimum requirements set by the new regulations are very basic, and the IRPH would still violate them. It requires, for example, making public the data used to develop the index, something that in the case of the IRPH is not met, claiming that it is secret data. In addition, the IRPH is not representative of the market and is not subject to the law of supply and demand, therefore it would violate two other minimum requirements. This Parliament must prevent families with fewer resources from being forced to pay up to three hundred euros more compared to mortgages that use the Eurobor as a benchmark. The IRPH is clearly abusive. It is leading the affected families first, to misery and then to eviction. This Regulation cannot leave any room for this abusive index to continue to be applied by banks.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, what is striking in the history of the benchmarks is that violations of the law have continued massively, well beyond the financial crisis. You would have thought that the financial crisis would have brought the industry down to a little more reason; but Deutsche Bank has been quoted as a huge financial institution, but there are many others, have been "having fun" manipulating these indicators for their benefit, for years, perhaps to this day. Some will say: "It is good, today they have been fined which are paid by the banks, not by individuals". I would remind you that in some countries these fines are even tax deductible, so they are paid by the taxpayer. So it was time, of course, for a new regulation to come to light, so I thank Cora van Nieuwenhuizen for the work she has done. We had a compromise almost to the end. In the end, however, some last-minute amendments effectively exempted from this regulation a series of indicators that would otherwise have been considered critical. As you have seen, we have a hard regime for critical indicators and a relaxed regime for indicators that are considered non-critical. A series of indicators are therefore exempt from this legislation. The only thing I can say is that I am pleased that the Member State that controls these indicators the most, the United Kingdom, has not waited for the European Parliament to adopt much stricter regulations than the one we are approving today. However, I wonder, much like Sylvie Goulard, that when it comes to financial regulation, when we know we have a single market, we are finally relying on the wisdom of the Member States, without much control for ESMA, for that matter, to enforce this regulation. We cannot therefore accept that the definition of a critical indicator should be left to the Member States. If we can still, at the last minute, amend the text tomorrow by the amendments we table, we will be part of the majority.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in view of the debates that have been devoted to this opinion on the benchmarks, we are tempted to find the result of this report, which provides for supervision alone, disappointing. The initial conclusion, however, is consensual: financial indices must be more strictly framed in order to avoid past scandals. I regret that the threshold for critical indices has been set too high and that the truly binding part of the regulation applies only to Libor and Euribor. But, beyond that, I would like to denounce, once again, some of the investment banks at the heart of the financial scandals, which force us to act. The Libor scandal is just one manipulation of the markets among others, such as those of the price of gold or Forex. It is in addition to the repeated HSBC scandals, money laundering, aid to tax evasion, indecent bonuses, subprime mortgages, etc. The more legislation is passed, the less state-constrained private banks are and the more they prosper on their backs. The few billion euros in fines are minimal given the stakes of tens of billions of euros a year in profit for fraudsters. The real question is how to break the infernal dynamics of finance without borders. For patriotic and serious economists, this is a no-brainer: to be effective, capital movement controls must be restored at national borders in order to limit speculation and short selling.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: – Confidence in our markets has suffered from scandals and allegations of manipulation of indicators. This must be put to an end and trust restored and more transparency given to the financial system. I therefore welcome this proposal and congratulate the colleagues who have worked on the report on creating a more balanced text that has overcome the problematic elements and can provide broad support. Most Member States of the European Union do not currently have a legal framework for the production of benchmarks at national level, enabling the establishment of a harmonised European criteria framework. The introduction of such a framework will improve the protection of consumers of financial services, increase confidence and the other will also contribute to improving financial stability at national and European level. However, it is also important to look at the consequences of the new rules on the overall financial market, for example if an initiative obliges contributors to significantly change their business models and there is a risk that they will reduce the number of services offered. It is therefore important to ensure that the new rules for contributors to benchmarks do not hinder innovation and do not create unnecessary burdens for business. In general, I support the report, which will increase the confidence of European citizens in the Financial System of the European Union and provide more transparency.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, congratulations to the rapporteur because this is a technical but critical subject. Basically, the reason we are gathered here around this text is because there was the Euribor scandal and the Libor issue, because these critical indices can jeopardize the stability of financial markets, weaken their functioning and, ultimately, have a real impact on the financing conditions of the economy. That is why there was an urgent need for the European Union to mobilise. But, of course, we are faced with a compromise, and I too regret that the powers of the supervisory authority - the authority which demonstrates day after day the strength of its analyses and recommendations - have not been further strengthened in terms of both the definition of critical indices and their supervision.  In the same way, I regret that the Member States have too much leeway in defining so-called non-critical indices.  Finally, one last point, Mr President, if I may. The European Union has a demanding legislation and intends to verify its equivalence with the laws of other parts of the world on the basis of what exists without taking into account the progress we are going to make here, referring only to the work of the IOSCO. I think there is room for manoeuvre there, and we should have gone further; but I, too, wish good luck to the negotiating team.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent The report provides the right solutions for indices in financial instruments and contracts. Much attention has been paid to the careful development of definitions and subsequent treatment of so-called key and non-key indicators, the treatment of commodity benchmarks, the exclusive principles of IOSCO to the Regulation and access to indicators used by third countries. The proposed regulations should contribute to improving the reliability of benchmarks, reducing their susceptibility to manipulation and indirectly increasing confidence in financial markets and improving the conditions under which they operate.  However, I would see a few areas here that could be further improved, particularly as regards the clarification of the rules setting out the scope of the projects, the introduction of more adequate rules or additional exemptions for certain categories of administrators, as well as the clarification of the transitional provisions. Thank you for your attention.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, Commissioner Hill, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work he has Robust and transparent benchmarks are important for the stability of the financial market. The volume of EUR 500 billion in financial constructs, financial contracts and financial instruments, based on benchmarks, shows us how essential today's report is and how important it is to bring transparency into the area of benchmarks. The Libor scandal has already been raised today. Here, too, it is clear that only transparency can resolve the conflict of interest between manipulation and abuse, transparency in both input data and methodology, because this became clear in the Libor scandal: one can agree on a common methodology, but if the input data is manipulated, one will not make any progress. This scandal has led to a record fine for Deutsche Bank – we heard it. This report is a first important step here, namely to create transparency and security, and also for the benchmark administrators, who will have to register with ESMA in the future. However, we in the European Parliament must go a step further. Leading banks and insurance representatives are now calling for better macro-prudential regulation to ensure financial stability. The European Parliament must take the next step here, and this is where we are called upon. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Mrs Kappel, considering the manipulations that took place on the markets – and there were a lot of them, by big financial institutions including big banks – and that in the end we leave the critical indicators to be established by each and every state, do you not think that the European Union should have to impose these critical indicators on all the financial institutions in all the European Union countries?

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I think that the rapporteur has managed to achieve a very balanced mix here, both in terms of the critical benchmarks you have mentioned and in terms of commodity benchmarks, financial benchmarks, large and small benchmarks. I very much agree with this report, and I believe that everything here is regulated in the appropriate form.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the starting point, in my view, concerns the excellent work that has been done in drawing up this report, because it respects the objective that we must set ourselves in the face of the critical underlying situation. The aim is to restore confidence. If, in the face of the condemnable scandals, we were to decide to activate a phenomenon of psychological terrorism, we would have given up the pursuit of our political task. So congratulations to the rapporteur and to those who have supported this work, which has as a balance, for example, in my view, the excellent choice to identify what are the distinctions between critical indices and indices that cannot be considered as such.  It is clear: my country, Italy, has also seen at this stage an important difficulty linked, for example, to a public prosecutor's office which, in relation to the risks linked to 2.5 million possible families damaged, has activated an international letters rogatory involving large European institutes. It is true that in Italy there is talk of Deutsche Bank being exposed for a quantity of derivatives that is five times the GDP of the eurozone, very well, but the approach is this: the solution to the problem, not the activation of further terror, of further mistrust. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to ask my colleague Mr Salini what he thinks will be the impact on small and medium-sized enterprises and how the bureaucracy in this area will develop. Will this have positive effects?

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: answer to a "blue card" question. Mr Rübig, I am pleased to answer your question. The concern about the effects that such a procedure can have on SMEs, on small and medium-sized enterprises, is a concern that I share, and I sometimes respond with difficulty to this question because, unfortunately, we have always seen consequences that do not live up to our questions.  I think the road is the right one. I believe that the first concern we must have is to force the European Union's credit institutions to put small and medium-sized enterprises back at the centre of their attention. What? How can this be achieved? It also involves a radical overhaul of the governance structure of credit institutions at European level, not just through the redefinition of financial benchmarks.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The manipulation of LIBOR and foreign exchange indicators by financial sector entities, banks and other investment funds has led both companies and retail investors to huge financial losses in recent years. While financial market regulators in Europe have penalised those who manipulated these indicators with penalties amounting to millions of euros, it is necessary to adopt rules at EU level to prevent such financial scandals in the future.  The regulation we are discussing today goes in this direction and focuses on achieving three objectives. Firstly, to strengthen management systems and standards, especially in the case of widely used systemically important indicators – so-called key indicators – and to reduce their vulnerability to manipulation and abuse. Secondly, increase transparency by making more information available to users of all indicators in order to enable them to make informed decisions. Thirdly, maintaining the supply and access to different benchmarks through the proportionate application of the requirements for their use.  I would like to express my hope that the application of this regulation in practice will contribute to a powerful reduction of fraud by the financial sector consisting in the manipulation of benchmarks.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Mr President, the European Union has been and is concerned about economic stability in general, but above all, the stability and proper functioning of financial and commodity markets. In this respect, the financial instruments used to conclude different financial contracts must benefit from clear but, above all, predictable legislation. We draw attention, however, to the fact that benchmarks can be means of market manipulation, which leads to the need to identify mechanisms and measures to prevent this, so that we do not have to deal with a distortion of these realities. The rapid evolution of markets must determine the factors responsible for finding a balance between the need for transparency and the ability of the user to impose discipline, with the major objective of discouraging the manipulation of benchmarks. In this respect, it is particularly important to bear in mind that different markets and economic realities always generate different types of benchmarks. The European Union must find mechanisms to regulate benchmarks when they take effect in several Member States, but leave these mechanisms to national states when they occur only at national level. In this respect, we must consider increasing standards and governance systems, as well as increasing transparency, enabling everyone to make informed decisions. Only in this way can we speak of fair competition for all managers, both at European Union level and at third country level.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Mr. President, I consider that a regulation is needed that will establish a legislative framework at Union level for indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts, the main reason being to ensure a high level of consumer and investor protection.  It is important to cover all benchmarks that determine the price of financial instruments or consumer contracts and measure the performance of investment funds. Ensuring the accuracy and correctness of the index is a key requirement to be ensured by this Regulation and I support the four main objectives for improving the framework in which benchmarks are set.  The impact on the Union budget must not be a stumbling block in the adoption of the regulation and I think that the benefits of stricter management and oversight of key benchmarks in establishing them will far outweigh the costs incurred. Cases of manipulation of benchmark interest rates have also, along with alleged manipulation of benchmarks in the energy and foreign exchange sectors, called for the adoption of such a regulation and that is why I support it.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the financial markets have on several occasions seen the manipulation of benchmarks for the determination of interest rates such as LIBOR and EURIBOR. Such manipulations, demonstrating that benchmarks can be subject to conflicts of interest and vulnerability, are important factors disturbing economic balances and cause considerable losses to consumers and investors, as well as destroying public confidence in the financial sector.  It is therefore certainly appropriate to restore confidence in the reference values, but not just to acknowledge the illegality of such behaviour. I therefore agree with the report, which considers it necessary to improve governance measures and mitigate conflicts of interest and which also aims to strengthen transparency and the implementation of access to a wide variety of values by applying governance requirements in a proportionate manner.  An increased, harmonised and flexible availability of reference values is appropriate in order to reduce the systemic importance of certain large values, so as to allow in a proportionate and transparent way all those who do business every day, invest, take a risk, obtain a credit to decide consciously.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, well-known banking giants such as Deutsche Bank have been punished with fines for manipulating the LIBOR benchmark, thus illegally earning hundreds of billions of euros. However, this is not enough since, after the financial crisis, the banks rescued with taxpayers' money are pursuing their tough and callous policy against micro-taxpayers and hammering thousands of homes in Southern Europe. name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I welcome the fact that in this report the S&D Group has managed to ensure a fair balance of requirements between critical and non-critical benchmarks, as well as the inclusion of commodity benchmarks. Therefore, as I mentioned before, I truly oppose the fact that critical benchmarks are left to be established by each and every Member State of the European Union. At the same time, I believe it is very important that a European legislative framework is going to be established in order to avoid the scandals and the market abuses that took place in the past. I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for the good balance reached in the text at the end.

name: Nathan GILL
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thanks to all the Members for the contributions they have made to what has been an excellent debate. First of all, there is clearly a lot of agreement: there is agreement on the need for us to take action to stop the kind of manipulation that we have seen too often in the past; there is agreement on the importance of transparency, and on the importance of better governance; agreement on the need to have better regulation and better supervision; and agreement that the rapporteur has come up with a good framework – although I recognise that some want to go further in some respects, whether on the question of supervision or on the definition of non-critical benchmarks.  Having listened to the debate, I am sure that we will find suitable common ground to make rapid progress on this file. That would be good for consumers, it would be good for investors, it would be good for confidence in markets and it would therefore be good for financial stability. I think that we need these safeguards in place as soon as possible. A number of honourable Members have talked about the length of time it has taken to get where we are now. Now we have an opportunity to take this proposal forward with the wind in our sails that I believe we have. That will help us ensure that robust benchmarks are used in EU markets to take action against manipulation and to prevent any failure of critical benchmarks. So I, on behalf of the Commission, would very much like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for all their hard work, which I think has been successful in moving forward with this legislation, and I very much look forward to a constructive set of negotiations in the trilogue and, I hope, a swift resolution to an issue that needs to be gripped.

name: Cora van NIEUWENHUIZEN
text: Rapporteur. I would like to thank all the speakers for their contribution and their valuable contribution today. I am very happy with the broad support. Of course, we have not been able to make everyone 100% happy, but I am glad that the report as a whole is widely supported by all of you. I would like to receive the expressions of appreciation and the compliments, but I would also like to share them with my collaborator, Koen ter Wal, who has put an awful lot of hard work into this. I would also like to remember the policy adviser of the ALDE Group, Petra, and the people in the Secretariat of the Committee on Economic Affairs. Because this was my first report, and it is quite a search to get through all the procedures in this House. So I am also very grateful to everyone who has contributed to this.  I would like to say to Mr Monot that he has seen it really wrong if he thinks that the critical benchmarks are all about LIBOR and EURIBOR, because that is really not the case. It is not for nothing that we have added qualitative criteria to this, apart from the quantitative criteria, so that there must always be an evaluation to see whether or not something is a critical benchmark.  I will not go into the content, because then the debate will take far too long. I very much look forward to going into the trialogues with the shadow rapporteurs and, of course, with the Commission and the Council, in order to take these important steps towards proper regulation of benchmarks as soon as possible.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. – I welcome this regulation: the benchmark scandals in the recent past clearly demonstrate what unregulated benchmarks can lead to. Manipulating benchmarks amounts to stealing from investors and consumers and undermines confidence in markets. The Commission fined the banks EUR 1.7 billion.  This regulation impacts consumersʼ daily lives as financial benchmarks determine the level of mortgage payments of millions of households in the EU. Banks stating they cannot invest in the real economy had made buffers to pay fines amounting to billions for the benchmark manipulation. The agreement we voted upon in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) is a balanced and proportional outcome: transparency and supervision on the benchmark process have been increased and conflicts of interest are tackled. name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
