But we also had the surprise that some banks even manipulated a number of indices (LIBOR), used as references in determining costs in credit agreements and other financial instruments such as, for example, home loans. Outrage for such manipulations cannot be measured. It's way too big. That is why we welcome this report which comes to ensure the accuracy and integrity of the process of establishing these indices. Greater transparency for this process, the prevention of conflicts of interest and improved governance will be ensured.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. – I would like to begin by congrating the rapporteurs of the various political groups, mainly Mr Ludek Niedermayer, because I believe that, with this legislative proposal, they have done a great job and have been ambitious in aspects such as proportionality. Recent cases of manipulation of interest rate benchmarks, such as the bookboard and euro-booker, have highlighted the importance of benchmarks and their vulnerability, and therefore the need for this legislative proposal by the European Commission. I am very pleased to see that we have managed to reach an agreement, bearing in mind that the negotiations began last parliamentary term with Sharon Bowles as rapporteur. Negotiations with the Council and the Commission should ensure that with this proposal we can establish a common framework to ensure the accuracy and completeness of the indices used as benchmarks in the Union's financial instruments and financial contracts, ensuring a high level of consumer and investor protection and establishing parence as one of the high priorities.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the own-initiative report by Pedra Silva Pereira, on behalf of the Committee on Development, on financing for development (2015/2044(INI)) (A8-0143/2015)

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, the report on post-2015 development finance, which I present here today and which will be voted on tomorrow, is the result of an intense and productive political debate in this Parliament, which has benefited from a very relevant participation of non-governmental organisations and civil society. The broad consensus reached in the Committee on Development, which I hope will be strengthened in tomorrow's plenary vote, was only made possible by the commitment effort of all the political groups, and therefore my first words are to thank all colleagues, especially the shadow rapporteurs, and also the committed support we have always had from the President of the Commission. Linda McAvan. We know that the price of extended commitments is often political irrelevance. Experience tells us that the search for a minimum common denominator often leads to empty proclamations, to the mere affirmation of general principles without practical implications. And in the end, we are all more or less in agreement, let's go home satisfied because each one reads in the text what suits him best. Fortunately, that is not the case with this report. My report proposes, without ambiguity, that the European Parliament make a choice, take a clear position and send a strong political message to the Commission, the Council, the Member States on the leading and responsible role that the European Union should have in the negotiations to be held at the 3rd International Conference on Financing for Development in Alse Ababa as early as next July. It is true that the new challenges we face are difficult and place differently the shared responsibility that was already placed in the Monterrey Consensus in 2002.  But what we are now about is very concrete things: - firstly, for the European Union to urgently reconfirm its commitment to allocate 0.7% of gross national income to official development aid. There can be no further delays or excuses because there will be no leadership by example in Addis Ababa without this commitment; - secondly, that the European Union give credibility to its commitment and to take a timetable for meeting that financial target by 2020; - thirdly, that 50% of this aid, at least 0.2% of gross national income, is reserved for the least developed countries and, because it would be a serious mistake to minimise the importance of public development aid, what needs to be done to do so. There are other topics on the table that will be discussed in Ababa and are also very important: mobilising the domestic resources of developing countries, which requires fairer and more efficient tax systems, more combating tax evasion and evasion, more international tax cooperation, including through an intergovernmental body for tax cooperation within the United Nations. It is also very important that the private sector is more aligned with the objectives of sustainable development, with a regulatory framework that favours it and also with financial instruments and incentive structures that ensure such alignment. Mr President, after the drama we are experiencing and seeing in the Mediterranean, development cooperation with the countries of origin of migration flows, of truly desperate refugees, reminds us also of the urgency of taking this commitment to development objectives seriously, but there will be no serious commitment without financing instruments that live up to our values and up to our responsibilities.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Committee on Development, its chair, Ms Linda McAvan, and the rapporteur, Mr Silva Pereira, for their dedicated work and for the openness of the consultations during the preparation of this report, which the Commission welcomes. It comes at a critical juncture in the post-2015 negotiations, and will make a valuable contribution to the ongoing debate in the Council, which is expected to adopt conclusions next week.  It is encouraging to see that the views of Parliament and the Commission are generally well aligned on the issues of financing for development. We share a vision of a global partnership to eradicate poverty, share prosperity and foster sustainable development while defending human rights, promoting gender equality and social cohesion, and reducing inequalities.  The report is very rich, covering a broad range of issues and making a number of requests to the Commission. I have taken careful note of these – including Member’s calls for increased attention to private sector investments, domestic revenue mobilisation, monitoring and transparency of the Commission’s own aid programmes and attention to the Court of Auditors’ reports on blending. This report will reinforce the European Union’s determination to call for and contribute to achieving a comprehensive global package comprising aid, investment and domestic resources, together with an enhancing framework of good policies and good governance. I welcome the clear support that the report expresses for an ambitious recommitment by the European Union to the 0.7 % of gross national income (GNI) for official development assistance (ODA) target, and to specific ODA targets for least developed countries.  As I have said to Parliament before, the Commission will help encourage Member States to reach an agreement on an ambitious package of measures for the implementation of the sustainable development agenda, including on the ODA commitment. However, the decision on the timetable for reaching the 0.7 % target is ultimately a decision for the Member States. Therefore, when it comes to the 2020 timetable proposed in the report, we need to consider carefully the political and economic realities within our Member States.  The Commission position has been that all developed countries should commit to the 0.7 % target, with the timetable to be set during the negotiation process. I believe we share the same objective: to ensure that the global agreement on financing for development includes ambitious and credible commitments from all. While I believe it is right that we also have expectations of others, we must be ready to play our full part by presenting our clear political commitment to ODA.  I also support the emphasis in the report on aid effectiveness and the need to ensure a higher degree of coordination between different aid mechanisms and donors. Furthermore, we note the call to step up international efforts to find additional climate finance. Mobilising more finance from all sources – public and private – to tackle climate change is, of course, a priority. But, we should be cautious about artificially dividing financing for climate and other development-related activities. Some climate change interventions, for instance, will meet the ODA definition. It is therefore important that synergies across various sustainable development objectives can be maximised to ensure that available resources can deliver the maximum impact.  We particularly welcome the emphasis in the report on the mobilisation and effective use of all forms of finance, including domestic resources, private investment, blending and innovative financial sources. To implement such a far-reaching agenda, we need to consider the full range of means of implementation. Good policies, trade, innovation policies and other non-financial resources will be just as crucial. They can make a real difference.  The Commission is cautious, however, about two recommendations in the report: to establish an intergovernmental body for tax cooperation and to establish a multilateral legal framework for sovereign debt restructuring. We are in favour of further discussions and analyses on these complex issues through an inclusive and participatory dialogue. The debate, in our view, should focus more on the substance rather than on the form and format of the statutory mechanisms of a multilateral legal framework.  The Commission is particularly cautious as regards the call for a multilateral legal framework for sovereign debt restructuring. Whilst finding sustainable debt solutions is highly important, the post-2015 negotiations should avoid pre-empting or duplicating ongoing work on sovereign debt restructuring in the context of other fora, notably the IMF.  The report contains many other interesting ideas and suggestions, which we will take carefully into account in finalising the EU position ahead of the Addis and New York conferences. I look forward to the discussion here today and to continuing the dialogue with this Parliament on the post-2015 agenda.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. Mr President, first of all, I thank Mr Pereira for introducing the debate with a report and a talented presentation. The vast majority of the Committee on Development is behind the conclusions drawn from this report, and I can only congratulate myself on the quality of what has emerged from our debates. The European Union will leave for Addis Ababa with good news and bad news. The good news is that it will, once again, commit to spending 0.7%, according to a timetable that depends on the Member States. The bad news: it had already made this commitment in Monterrey, in the context of an identical conference, where the timetable also depended on the Member States. Member States that have met the 0.7% target will be able to congratulate themselves and proclaim their mission accomplished in Addis Ababa. The others only have to reread the speeches they already gave in Monterrey a dozen years ago. Schematically, this conference has two components: a quantitative component and a qualitative component. The quantity, as I said, has been the subject of various commitments that have not been kept. Quality must, of course, be directed at those who need money most for official development assistance. This quality must respond to indicators of efficiency, relevance and also sustainability to respond, in fact, to the OECD's method of doing so. We must also add that aid must be predictable, in order to enable the major players in official development assistance to rely on predictability that allows them to make longer-term commitments. Hence the invitation to the Member States and the Commission to do so and not to arrive empty-handed in Addis Ababa. Finally, I would like to emphasise the principle of differentiation: if we are to act effectively in the area of official development assistance, we will have to apply this principle, which the Commission is calling for and which we have supported, which aims to remind those who generate enough resources today to support themselves , especially middle-income countries, so that we can focus our aid on those in dire need.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the I would also like to thank Commissioner Mimica and the rapporteur, Pedro Silva Pereira. We worked well together. I believe it is important to work out good solutions with the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs. I believe that this report clearly sums up our wishes. We all know that, of course, the Court of Auditors has also looked at what has happened here since 2002, particularly in terms of expenditure here. There is certainly a need for action and improvement. But our aim is to offer perspectives to people in the least developed countries. That is why it is also a question of how we finance joint development aid in the future. The target of 0.7% is undisputed. The only question is when it can be achieved. After all, we have states in Europe that are struggling themselves and on the verge of illiquidity. That is why I believe that a general, general solution is not possible in a short period of time. I believe that by 2020 we should be watching to ensure that all the Member States of the European Union reach this 0.7% in order to improve the economic environment in the least developed countries. It is also, of course, a question of achieving greater efficiency on the expenditure side. It is not enough just to give money. Money alone is not enough – you cannot eat that – but it is very much a question of considering new structures on how to help on the ground in the various areas, e.B. in the area of health – we have seen in the case of Ebola that this has been designed very effectively – and, of course, also in the areas of education, energy and water supply. Sanitary facilities serve to strengthen health accordingly.

name: Norbert NEUSER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Congratulations also to my colleague Silva Pereira, who has produced a good report. The problem is not the good report. The problem is not a great deal of agreement here in the Committee on Development or in Parliament. The problem is our Member States. I just want to focus my speech on the fact that we have major omissions here. It is about the credibility of the EU and it is about the credibility of the Member States. I come from Germany, a not exactly poor country. But Germany is failing on this issue. Germany has hardly developed any progress in the commitments. Germany has so far achieved 0.4% instead of 0.7%. We have four countries in Europe that have achieved this goal; let us also be clear: these are great Britain, Sweden, Denmark and Luxembourg. And the other Member States are sticking to the noble target of 0.7%. But there is not even agreement on the timetable. This is a single disgrace to our Member States. I would like to add a second: of course we need more money, of course we need more effectiveness. But sometimes it would also help if we, as rich countries, simply took less away from poor countries. In this context, I would like to refer once again to the debate on conflict minerals. I hope that, when it is being put in place, one or the other group will reconsider its position.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank Mr Pereira for a timely and essential report on the challenge posed to us by Addis Ababa. We can eradicate poverty, but we must strip ourselves of the rich world's own prejudices and ideological constraints that hurt the operational excellence of this struggle. When we talk about financing for development, we are not just talking about securing sufficient funds, solidarity and at least 0.7% of GDP to achieve the sustainable development goals. Above all, we are talking about effective and consensual policies to make appropriate use of these funds from multiple funders, public and private, national and international. We are talking about channeling this funding into key development factors, such as local governance, infrastructure, human capital, trade, green energy technology and biodiversity.  Esther Duflo, the brand new Princess of Asturias Award for Social Sciences, has scientifically proven that determined, gradual and ambitious action can effectively and sustainably eradicate ultra-overness by 2030. Comprehensive programmes, with comprehensive interventions in various areas, can break the trap of poverty around the axes of universality of human rights and gender equality.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I too congratulate Mr Pereira on his report and thank him very much for the effort. Today poverty and inequality, far from slowing down, continue to rise. As the International Labour Organization points out, it is urgent to develop a binding framework of social guarantees for all – including basic income – that guarantee dignity and human rights. But to do so, the mobilization of national financial resources through fair taxation in all States is necessary. It is essential to focus on combating tax fraud and illicit capital trafficking, as well as strengthening fair, progressive and redistributive tax systems. Austerity policies are condemning many people to pay for the recklessness and greed of a few, which are enriched while the vast majority continue to become impoverished. The lack of a regulatory framework based on mutual responsibility of lenders and borrowers, which analyses the legitimacy and sustainability of states' sovereign debt, has become a global problem and a drag on endogenous development. To this end, it is prevailing that the European Commission and the Member States will work together on the work that is beginning to take place at the United Nations for the creation of a sovereign debt restructuring framework. Without responsibility and without coherence in addressing financing for development, it is impossible to address poverty and inequality at the global level. They can be fought: only political will is necessary, and I hope we have it.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: On behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Verts/ALE). – Mr President, this is a real super-year of development policy. We have a European Year of Development and two important meetings. In Addis Ababa, the future of development funding will be decided and then, a little later this year, the UN will agree on new global sustainable development goals. We must not fail at this financial conference in Addis Ababa, because it is really about facing huge global challenges. Above all, of course, the fight against poverty: it is no longer enough to halve poverty; We have new challenges which, in fact, are not so new, but which are increasingly of increasing acute importance. I am thinking, for example, of climate change, and in that sense it is also very important that the rapporteur has, in the final stages, brought forward a proposal for an amendment in which he emphasises the utmost importance of helping communities to become more resilience against all such natural disasters, which are also caused by climate change. I would like to stress that the Council should not now impose any additional restrictions and conditions on this objective of implementing official development aid, but that the 0.7% target must be achieved without reference to any acute economic situation, because one can only imagine how bad the developing countries will be if we suffer from bad economic conditions here. This 0.7% is not only a kind of global tax that we need to implement, but it is also all the things that the committee emphasises that are part of this palet, especially the collection of taxes in developing countries, so that they can finance their own activities. We must also be able to look at how new means of financing are found. Finally, I would like to say that nothing will work unless development policy is compatible with all other policy areas.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too wanted to congratulate the rapporteur, the shadow rapporteurs and the non-governmental organisations that have helped to draw up this report. We are talking about development funding and the Addis Ababa Conference. And it is important that we come to this conference with a strong, decisive and clear position because, probably, when we discuss the problems of the world, the importance of development cooperation is probably not yet very clear.  Today we are constantly witnessing tragedies related to immigration, linked precisely to the merchandise of people and to continuous deaths in the Mediterranean. Perhaps if there had been more attention to development cooperation in the developing countries, in the countries from which we are fleeing, in the transit countries, these tragedies could be addressed differently. We know very well – and there is no point in us circling around – that very often our own countries go to these countries to exploit resources, to generate civil wars. And then we find ourselves, as Mr Neuser rightly said, talking about official development funding with the richest countries in Europe, including Germany, which does not even want to put 0.7% of gross national income and is limited to 0.4%. That is why we hope, at least, that the Council will be able to find a shared position, that this type of assistance will be made compulsory. I also believe that, in addition to official funding, there is a kind of unconventional financing, an alternative funding that the Member States endorse when it is the multinationals of the same states that have an interest in creating their own kind of development in these countries. From here, in short, we hope that from this step we can turn the page for incisive action from this Conference.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: – Development aid is not taking the rich and giving to the poor: it is catching the poor and handing it out to the rich. The most poignant example is the EUR 234 million that the European Commission has transferred to Mr Mugabe. Mr Mugabe, who then, as a token of appreciation, slaughtered two elephants and set up a large barbecue. This EUR 234 million is hard-earned tax money. Money for which people in the Netherlands and the rest of Europe have to work hard. These people pay that tax on the assumption that they are handled with care. But what is the European Commission doing? He gives this hard money to a corrupt African dictator! How hard can it be to empathe in people who pay taxes?

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: – Mr President, the recurrent tragedies in the Mediterranean, in which thousands of people are risking their lives almost on a daily basis in order to reach the shores of Europe, clearly show an ever growing need to continue, strengthen and also refocus our development policy and to rethink the ways of financing development. Poverty, war and also the lack of freedom and bad governance is what makes desperate people undertake dangerous journeys in the search for a better life in Europe, and development cooperation is an important part of the answer to this challenge. We all agreed at the last session in Strasbourg that development is important, but we need to remember it now when we are talking about the financial contributions. Thus I support the rapporteur and the Commission in their call to the Member States to recommit to devoting 0.7% of GNI to official development assistance: yes, taking into account national budgetary constraints, but also taking into account the fact that the EU needs to remain the leader of global development efforts. I also share the rapporteur’s views that we need a truly global partnership and that all developed countries as well as emerging and middle-income economies should take their fair share of the burden in the fight against poverty. Furthermore, we need a completely new approach to financing development. We need to go beyond Official Development Assistance (ODA) and work on mobilising all types of finance: public and private, international and domestic. In all these efforts ahead of the 13th National Conference in Addis Ababa, we need to be aware of the fact that finance alone will not be sufficient. Policies are of fundamental importance in achieving sustainable development goals. We need policies that will ensure that financial resources are used effectively and in areas that will bring further mobilisation of resources and sustainable development. We need to invest in enablers of development and yes, most of all, we need to invest in good governance. If we get back, for example, to the issue of migration we will see that this is the key question – the question of governance. Many migrants are not even extremely poor, but they are all extremely desperate. They are ready to give thousands of euros to traffickers because there is not good governance. Therefore, our development policy needs to focus on this, and the Conference in Addis Ababa could be an important opportunity to make a significant step in that direction. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to ask Mr Stier what he thinks of the idea that family farms in developing countries should also be supported, because they are ultimately developing prosperity. It is not just a question of spending money, but of helping people to help themselves. And only when prosperity is developed can a state take the necessary tax revenue. Do you believe that it is possible to create fair situations in the poorest of the poor countries, even with better financial management?

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, I do agree with that, Mr Rubig, and that is why I said that we also need to invest and support those who could be enablers of development – those who could, through their contribution and growth, support sustainable development in their countries. Of course, supporting SMEs, supporting family business, should be seen in that context. From my side I can agree with you.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to congratulate the rapporteur and those who have worked on this report. 2015, the European Year of Development, could mark a turning point. In September, we should agree at the UN on the new sustainable development goals, which apply to everyone. The new agenda must be ambitious, but in order for these objectives to be truly achieved, including by completing the unfinished work of the Millennium Development Goals, we must have the necessary resources to do so. Mr Silva Pereira's report makes this clear: the success of the post-2015 agenda will also depend on the level of ambition that will be demonstrated at the Addis Ababa Conference. And if we claim European primacy as the first donors, we must commit ourselves once again and indeed to allocating 0.7% of gross national income to official development aid, presenting timetables in stages to achieve the objective that must not be conditioned by other donors. Equally important, and this is well highlighted in the report, is the mobilisation of national resources, the most important source of funding for developing countries; we need to strengthen international cooperation in the field of taxation and aid in this respect: this is essential not only to achieve new objectives but also to enable dependence on foreign aid to be overcome in the long term. Linked to this is the global issue of tax avoidance and evasion, which cause huge losses to developing countries, which risk nullifying aid. Combating these practices must therefore be a priority for the European Union. I have heard what the Commissioner says, and we will certainly talk about it again, but I think it is important that we finally talk about a truly intergovernmental body where developing countries can participate on an equal footing in rewriting global tax rules.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, relations of asymmetric interdependence, typical of global capitalism, are the brainchild of unequal development on a global scale. The North-South fracture is probably the most obvious and vivid expression of this inequality, not the only one. With economic inequality comes political dependence and subordination.  There are several instruments that promote this cycle of increasing impoverishment, dependence and subordination. This is the case of external debt, which is repeatedly paid and, nevertheless, always increasing. There will be no serious or effective development cooperation policy without addressing this issue, nor without the essential cancellation of this debt and the mechanisms that underpin it. It is not about solidarity, it is a question of basic justice. In the name of debt, the interventions of the IMF and the World Bank deeply weaken the already fragile economies of developing countries and promote the drainage of endogenous resources to so-called donors, resources that exceed the amounts of official development aid, thereby accentuating inequality.  Official development aid is crucial and should increase, even in accordance with international commitments made but not fulfilled, but it is not sufficient in itself and cannot serve as a screen to hide the disastrous effects of sectoral policies, based on protectionism of the rich, trade liberalisation, the deregulation of the financial system, tax havens, nor to export and impose models of economic and political organisation that , so often, they disrespect the sovereignty, needs and legitimate choices of developing countries.

name: Nathan GILL
text: – Mr President, I would like to make two points. One is on setting targets and the second is on aid-giving itself. This institution believes that nations setting targets of 0.7% of GNI and an EU foreign aid budget of EUR 960 billion can only have positive outcomes. As is always the case, just throwing money at problems seldom solves the problem. The reality is that the culture of targets has caused an environment of deceit. In the UK, the Conservative Government is very proud of the fact that we achieved the target of 0.7% of GNI last year. The British Department for Foreign Aid and Development forced civil servants to go on a GBP 1 billion spending spree at the end of 2013 just to hit that target. We have food banks, a GBP 30 billion black hole in our NHS, potholes everywhere, a failing education system, underfunded police with bobbies being taken off the beat everywhere, thousands of policemen being taken away from service, and reduced bin collection – now fortnightly and, in some places, monthly. Libraries are closing, post offices are closing and street lights are being switched off. We can use that GBP 11.4 billion much better in the UK than giving it, in many cases, to dictators and people who squander it. My second point is that there is no guarantee that the aid that we give to some of the poor countries has had any lasting effect whatsoever. Some of the countries are still as poor as they were 20 years ago. I ask this institution to remove the barriers it has placed on these countries; remove the common fisheries policies from their shores and allow them to sell their goods at a rate that suits them. Increase the trade, decrease the aid and you will see that poorer countries will start to flourish. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162((8))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Mr Gill, as you know, most of the official development assistance goes in some years to countries from Asia and Africa that are members of the Commonwealth. Do you know that the UK plays a very important role within that organisation? Do you intend to decrease the role of your country, considering the support given to Commonwealth states, given what you said this evening? Do you not think that the UK should have to maintain its role as a leader of the Commonwealth, supporting all those countries which are members of the Commonwealth?

name: Nathan GILL
text: blue-card answer. – In a word: yes. We need to reduce the foreign aid that we are giving, regardless of whether it is to the Commonwealth or not. I come from a country which has suffered very badly from the economic problems started in 2008. We have not recovered from it. Why is it that we are taxing widows and old people in my country in order to give foreign aid, in many cases in very ill-thought-out situations?  It is immoral of any government to tax people to give aid. My nation already gives GBP 9 billion a year through charity donations to charities like Oxfam and so forth, which is already 0.7% of our GDI. We do not need to tax people in order to do that. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: blue-card question. – Mr Gill, I believe that the UK has been a really delightful example in that it does not separate global problems from solving problems at home, and I believe that, at the end of the day, we all should agree that there is no security at home unless there is security worldwide. The UK, I think, has been exemplary also in looking for results and measuring those results. I do not personally always agree with their approach of value for money – how many vaccinations, how many school books have been delivered – but they are really looking at those results. So do you not agree that the UK has quite a good administration to govern development policy?

name: Nathan GILL
text: blue-card answer. – I think we are improving, without a doubt, because there have been some extremely bad circumstances and situations where aid has hit all the headlines for all the wrong reasons. But the reality is that we have a GBP 96 billion deficit, we have a GBP 1.5 trillion national debt. We cannot borrow money to give in aid. When we sort our house out, when we get our own house in order, then we will be in a situation to help other people more strongly. But until we get our house in order, I do not believe that putting my grandchildren into debt is a wise move in this situation.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Investing in development would be good investment in peace and stability, but unfortunately, financing is often ineffective. We therefore need a greater sense of responsibility, not only for the sake of the countries in need, but also out of respect for our taxpayers. According to a newspaper report, at least EUR 1 billion disappeared without a trace in 2013, and mr van Rompuy, then President-in-Office of the Council, simply spoke of overlooking the extent of this corruption. The Member States are therefore being asked to increase development aid. But, as the example of Congo shows, there is no traceability. It is therefore called for this traceability to be reviewed. Unfortunately, a great deal of money goes directly into the budgets of the developing countries. It is difficult to understand what is actually happening with the money. We therefore need transparency, clarity and control over these funds and flows of money before we think in principle of an increase.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This year will be the decisive year in which the Millennium Development Goals, which have been the basis for development cooperation for the last 15 years, will cease to apply. They will be replaced by new targets. The Addis Ababa Conference in July this year is expected to discuss the continuation of ODA at 0.7% as a key contribution to ensuring the ambitious outcome of the post-2015 negotiations.  Future SDGs aim to eradicate poverty by 2030 To do so, they must take into account the multipolar nature of the world, the changing geography of poverty, the effects of global challenges such as climate change and new security threats, disease epidemics and armed conflicts, and the transformation of development funding. In recent years, the European Union has maintained its place as the world's leading donor of official development assistance despite the difficult economic situation. Nevertheless, we still have a long way to go to achieve our ambitious goals. I am therefore firmly convinced that the search for innovative sources of financing for development aid is a very important and important issue. One of the ideas for these innovative sources of funding may be the so-called microscopic solidarity contribution. Some companies plan to spend a certain percentage of their money on development aid from advertisers. Such initiatives have the opportunity to raise the necessary resources relatively quickly, which is extremely important if we want to continue our achievements in terms of health aid, access to education, hygiene, drinking water, the fight against malnutrition or environmental protection. Thank you very much.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Mr President, Mr Mimica, commitments without real political will to fulfil them and political will without economic means are empty words which are often more negative than silence itself. I believe that Addis Ababa is the place to make commitments, to express a clear political will to fulfill them and to put the means to move forward.  Taking advantage of the presence in our House of the Vice-President in charge of the Budget and former Commissioner for Humanitarian Affairs, I have to say that in Sendai, at the Conference on Disaster Risk Reduction, a large framework has been adopted that serves everyone, but the economic means for the meeting of Addis Ababa have been postponed. And I believe that in Addis Ababa we must make a commitment to contribute money for humanitarian action in terms of reducing natural risks. I would like to point out that the Commission complies. May the States comply and fulfill all those who have to put the means to end that in this world there are a few islands of great well-being in the midst of an ocean of immense poverty!

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: – Mr President, first of all, I regret the selfish tinge that this debate is taking at times. I believe that the European Union is giving nothing, absolutely nothing, to impoverished countries. We are only giving a handout to continue to maintain the looting of Africa, to continue stealing its resources. That is why I would like to say that I fully agree with the need to maintain and take on financing for development, but that this report does not touch on important aspects, such as whether poverty is to be tackled, that there is not a single line on how to eradicate hunger, not a single line to support the local peasant , not a single line to end land grabbing, not a single line, in short, to put an end to this looting. Nor is there a single line about the European Union's responsibility for conflicts in these States. I would like to say, finally, too, that, when we talk about the private sector, I would like to see a question of what we are talking about: whether we intend to finance with these funds the relocation of European companies or whether we will support local small businesses. (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Mr President, as representatives of the peoples of Europe, we have an obligation to put the dignity of citizens, the end of poverty and the transformation of citizens' lives at the centre of all development activities. The report under discussion talks about development funding for the poor, gender-sensitive and climate-safe. It speaks of sustainable development, of public goods and important commitments: I fully agree on the content, but I disagree as to who this aid is addressed to. You will all agree - because we are all experiencing the economic crisis, some less so - that talking about official development aid and sustainable development goals for developing countries is an oxymoron, in a Europe of poverty, poverty and unemployment. It is very difficult to explain to the citizens of Greece why social resources should be made available to third countries and not to combat inequalities within the European Union.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Development is, of course, in the interest not only of the poor, but also of the rich. For the world has become one great village. However, financing for development to be effective must be effective and not achieve efficiency in financing development without applying specific priorities.  When I read the report on financing development, however, it is difficult to capture the priorities there: everything is said there. This is actually a development strategy that could be attributed to every country and any organisation, but it must be set on very clear objectives and very clear priorities. I would also m.in education, for example, because investment in human capital is probably the foundation of success in general when it comes to the development of the countries that we mean.  Secondly, the development of entrepreneurship, especially micro and small businesses in such countries. Implementing programs that you could define as "working for yourself and working for others" is something worth investing in.  Thirdly, civil society and free media. I hardly read about free media in this report at all, and without civil society, without free media, there is no effective control, there is waste and corruption.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, if we truly want to ensure that 2015 is the Year of Development, we must have a successful strategy and the powerful means that will enable us to accomplish the Millennium Development Goals that we are negotiating this year. This is why the EU and its Member States must recommit without delay to the 0.7 % of GNI target for official development assistance (ODA) with 50 % of ODA and at least 0.2 % of GNI reserved for the least developed countries, and to present, taking into account budgetary constraints, multiannual budget timetables for the scale—up to these levels by 2020. Indeed, the problem stays with the Member States of the European Union. I support the view adopted in the report when it states that domestic resource mobilisation is more predictable and sustainable than foreign assistance and must be a key source of financing. Public aid alone is not sufficient to cover all investment needs in developing countries. The EU must set up a regulatory framework, together with developing countries, that stipulates more responsible, transparent and countable investment, contributing to the development of a socially conscious private sector in developing countries.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Ahead of the funding conference in Addis Ababa and a year before the revision of the EU budget 2014-2020, I would like to focus on two main aspects. The first is that a total of 0.7% of gross national income should go to development cooperation from each Member State. EU Member States committed themselves to this again in 2000. However, only four Member States have achieved this objective, and Unfortunately Germany is not included either. The second is political coherence in terms of development policy, so that the money is used in a targeted manner and does not seep in and other potentials are exploited. All European Union policies, such as .B trade, environment, agriculture, education and financial policies, need to be further interlinked. The EU's objectives of reducing poverty in developing countries, strengthening women and girls in these countries and improving education can only be achieved through political coherence. This can reduce the flow of refugees in which people risk their lives. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: João FERREIRA
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". – Mr President, Mr Lietz spoke of policy coherence. It's a very important issue. In the 19th century, the Dominican Lacordaire, in a maxim that would become famous, said: "between the weak and the strong, between the rich and the poor, it is freedom that oppresses and it is the law that frees". I wonder whether this transposed to our day i would not advise reversing the policies of trade liberalisation and deregulation of international trade that are so damaging to these countries, but which their group has defended.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I would like to take an example on the issue of coherence. We, as European Social Democrats, have just fought to ensure that fishing rights, fishing in other seas, are fairer or reduced to quotas. This is a key point, an example, where policy coherence can and must be divided not only on giving money, but also on acting fairly and participating in trade together. In this area, for example, we need to monitor quotas much more closely and use new control mechanisms to actually achieve this objective.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the international community in Addis Ababa will have to present itself with its cards in order, otherwise it will not be credible in international peace and development policy. It is a vital problem for the developed world to find a path to fairer development to stop migratory flows, to combat poverty and hunger. We therefore insist, knowing the concerns of the governments, that each country should honour its commitments of 10 years ago, that of reaching 0.7% for the least developed countries. In addition to public resources, we need a proper and useful mobilisation of private investment resources in order to create productive realities in the least developed countries, to support local micro-entrepreneurship (what women's cooperatives do and can do in Africa!) and to find all the resources on the ground to grow sustainfully. We must also support the return of migrants to their countries through productive initiatives, taking advantage of the skills acquired here, and we must take a good look at what happens to remittances so that this is a non-exploitation and reduction of resources that can return to productive use in these countries.  I would like to talk about corruption, but there is no more time.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: Mr President, this catalogue of basic principles and good feelings is intended to give back hope and dignity to a part of humanity. But this resolution is, in the current state of global geopolitics and the financialization of the economy, perfectly unworkable and largely utopian. Who controls the use of these funds? How can we fail to see that many dictatorships are doing rather well with the consent and complicity of our democracies or, worse, the large commercial or oil industrial companies that control these markets and sometimes these regimes? No self-criticism about our own model, our actions, our political faults in foreign policy. Not talking today about immigration and regulating flows or shared corruption between the North and the South aggravates imbalances, multiplies human disasters and, ultimately, does not solve anything.  We must stop showing this neo-ecolonialism of humanitarian and too often commercial essence to get out of this global hypocrisy as soon as possible.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, while the Millennium Development Goals were mostly about poverty eradication, the new goals are a lot wider in ambition, seeking to alleviate poverty, to achieve equitable and sustained economic growth, to protect the environment and to promote peaceful and inclusive societies where human rights everywhere are respected.  Compared to the last period’s eight goals, we are currently faced with proposals for 17 goals and almost 200 targets. We should be careful not to divert this process into a bureaucratic nightmare but to reach an agreement on development policy that is comprehensive and clear, can be easily monitored and is also in line with other international framework agreements such as the one on climate change.  In order to reach a strong agreement and financing partnership it is absolutely imperative that the EU and its Member States, the largest donor of aid, continue to assume their responsibility in negotiations and make renewed commitments in the case of both high- and medium-income countries.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe has set itself a very ambitious objective: the eradication of poverty as the main task of its development cooperation policy.  The figures tell us that it cannot be an objective that remains on paper. In the European Year of Development, efforts must be concentrated in support of the one and a half billion people who are still in extreme poverty today. However, the commitment must be clear: the stronger countries must fulfil their commitment to allocate 0.7% of gross national income as official development aid. The Addis Ababa International Forum next July is an opportunity to sign these commitments. European countries are the largest donors of development aid and it is right that they should lead the funding process for these countries. It is clear that the funds – without an effective and effective investment strategy in education, agriculture and training – are in danger of ending up in the loop of corruption and illicit trafficking, they risk benefiting the oligarchy that forces these very countries into poverty.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, there can be no development of states as long as the states are burdened with unafforded debts. That is why the RESOLUTION of the UN General Assembly of September 2014 on the restructuring of sovereign debt must be implemented immediately, so that loan lenders and the IMF stop treating sovereign states as businesses. That is why the state debts of the developing world must be erased. Within the euro area, states that have entered into a memorandum must take advantage of European Union Regulation 472/2013 and proceed with debt auditing and then write-off of shameful debt. My home country of Greece, over the last five years, while taking 214 billion euros from the IMF and the European Union in the form of loans, has over one and a half million unemployed and thousands of poor people. Where did the money go? Didn't they go back to the lenders' pockets? But that's exactly what happened. And that, then, the speculative gaitanaki must stop. And that will be when Greece proceeds to write off the shameful debt.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, the response to global poverty and Mr. Commissioner, as you have also determined, a global partnership. A global partnership with the civilian sector and a global partnership with the private sector. I think your concept is well placed and of course the concept of the European Union, as a leader in solidarity and in what global poverty eradication means.  I want to make it very clear here that I expect that you and the Commission of the European Union will fully lead the fight against poverty that is still global, that is still huge, that is still great and that with partners, with those who are our wealthy partners, with whom we share in some way the good fate of this planet of ours, that it is with these partners that , wealthy partners, let's eradicate poverty together.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). – I welcome the emphasis with which the introduction of today's development debate in states outside the Union calls for sustainable solutions to the problems of public debt. I underline the reference in the motion to the need for a stable legal framework for the restructuring of public debts, where necessary, with a view to debt relief and avoiding unsustainable over-indebtedness of states. But the problem exists not only for third world countries, but also within the Eurozone itself, where a number of states have adst lip to more than 120% of their GDP, more than double the threshold allowed under the Maastricht Treaty. We cannot continue to turn a blind blind to this huge problem that lies within our own home and threatens the foundations of the Union and we can only talk about the third world. Put aside the ideas of austerity and breathe new life into societies by restructuring the debt of the over-indebted.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – 1.5 billion people are still living in poverty because they are facing a shortage of health, education and living standards, and usually every new virus that is created naturally or in laboratories is most affected. Official Development Assistance is therefore a key instrument for financing development, but unfortunately few countries fully respect their commitments to provide aid on gross national income. Above all, of course, it is also necessary to look for options in cooperation with private resources, so-called blending funds, while of course taking into account that these funds achieve their objective and therefore not only a one-off, short-term impact, but that there are long-term effects, which, of course, must also be properly supervised for these projects, so that appropriate planning and selection of projects and evaluation of projects implemented and evaluation of projects implemented are necessary and that the projects implemented are properly controlled. , otherwise the money may go into the wrong hands.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Parliament for this rich and engaging discussion. I commend and congratulate the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs once again for this excellent report. A number of important points have been raised here today, and I have taken good note of them.  Today’s discussion, along with the report, is a very welcome and useful contribution to our ongoing discussion with the Member States in order to finalise a compelling EU position ahead of this year’s conferences.   As confirmed by the Commission in our February communication, the Commission is of the opinion that the European Union should maintain its collective commitment to achieving the 0.7% of GNI target for ODA and should also commit to the 0.15-0.20% of GNI as the ODA target for the least developed countries. I believe the ODA commitment matters. It is important for our own development credibility, as well as for the success of the international conferences in Addis Ababa, New York and Paris this year.  At the same time, we must recognise that ODA alone will not be nearly enough to finance such a far-reaching, broad new global development agenda. Therefore we must envisage a new, more strategic and functional additional role for ODA by using it in a more catalytic manner to engage and leverage other financial and non-financial means of implementation that would suffice to cover such a demanding new SDG agenda.  I think that, above all, today’s debate has underlined that both the Commission and Parliament share a firm desire to ensure that the European Union plays a leading role in supporting the adoption and implementation of a truly transformative post-2015 agenda, by raising the global level of ambition. It is in this way that we should be able to claim that the European Union is not only the biggest player in global development cooperation, but also the best – the most effective – player. I will continue to work with fellow Commissioners, the European Parliament and Member States to ensure that the European Union is well positioned to do so.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank the words of support for my report by the colleagues who participated in this debate and I would also like to welcome the constructive position of the European Commission and the communication it has presented and to acknowledge Commissioner Mimica's personal commitment. We know well that the resistance to concrete financial commitments comes from the Council and the Member States, not so much from the Commission. But there is a clear political message in the report. In the European Union's position for the Conference on Financing for Development, there has been a certain lack of commitment to financial targets so far. And it is this lack of commitment to the financial targets and their timetable that we hope will be corrected, if possible at the next Council meeting. The political position that Parliament will vote on is in this direction and we hope that the Commission and the Council can take it into account. I would then like to stress that we can demand more from others, from emerging countries, from other international partners, from developing countries, but we can and must also demand more from ourselves, because the challenges challenge our values and because we fall short of the commitments we have made, in particular with the 0.7% of development support. And without ambition at the Ababa Conference, without adequate funding, the sustainable development goals, however beautiful they may be, will not come out of the paper. That is the challenge we have before us, to be up to our responsibilities and to be up to our values.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. – Developing countries have a higher proportion of people with disabilities, who very often live in extreme poverty and do not have basic human rights. The European Year of Development is a unique opportunity to do something about it. But the elimination of poverty and inequality can only be achieved by mobilising sufficient and adequate resources for all and by better targeting marginalised groups, such as children, women, the elderly or people with disabilities. Illegal capital outflows from developing countries amount to US$1 000 billion, which is 10 times the amount of official development assistance. It is therefore necessary to strengthen the ability of developing countries to collect taxes by strengthening the areas of tax administration, financial management and public finance management. Improving the quality of statistics, data and information requires international cooperation, including data on income, gender, age, race and ethnicity, migration status, disability, geographical location and other relevant characteristics in the national context. Only in this way can transparent and effective implementation of aid and funding be ensured, in particular by signing and effectively implementing the provisions of the UN Convention against Corruption.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. It is easy for collective consciences not to accept the idea that 1.5 billion people live in extreme poverty, with all kinds of deprivations in terms of health, education and living standards. It is more difficult, however, to put a gradual end to this situation, with structured interventions that use sufficient resources at world level.  Next July, the third international conference on development finance in Addis Ababa has the ambitious task of setting the level of intervention in the next agenda on the subject.  I agree with the report, which welcomes the preliminary draft of the final document of the third conference. I am aware that the right conditions for the eradication of poverty and inequality can be achieved above all by a universal, holistic and integrated approach, which is also entrusted to the Monitoring and Monitoring by the Commission of the financing of aid programmes and projects on health, education, energy, water supplies and infrastructure. Each action involves the establishment of a correct economic framework, designed to combat corruption, avoid mismanagement and, in short, affirm adequate political leadership in these processes.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. – The European Union is an important player in international development, accounting for almost 60% of official global development aid. There are many aspects that can be improved. We must encourage the fight against tax evasion. There is also the possibility of very high risks that can lead to a debt bubble in countries with limited incomes.  More funding is needed in science, research, development and technology. We must not forget micro-enterprises and small and medium-sized enterprises, because they play a fundamental role in job creation and inclusive growth. Aid programmes and projects are needed to take appropriate action in the event of evidence of corruption and mismanagement of funds in developing countries.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: sit. – The next item is the Commission Declaration on Tobacco Agreements (2015/2686 (RSP))

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Parliament for the invitation to deliver a Commission statement on the tobacco agreements. These agreements have been introduced with the support of this House as an instrument in our fight against cigarette smuggling, with the first one signed in 2004.  Then, and now, Parliament has been our key ally in the fight against cigarette smuggling, a criminal act that siphons away money from our budgets. We know the data: around EUR 10 billion are lost every year as a result of smuggling, which impacts primarily on our Member States but also on the EU budget. Just to put this in perspective, our 28 Member States in 2013 had fiscal income from legal cigarette sales of over EUR 90 billion. That means that because of this criminal activity they have lost more than 10% of income that would have benefited their citizens, and that makes fighting cigarette smuggling financially very important. We also recognise the negative impact on our public health policies. Legislative restrictions in the EU and national level prices are designed to deter smoking, and to protect citizens, especially youngsters. In contrast, illicit tobacco products are available, including to young people, at a substantial illegal discount. There is also a security dimension, since cigarette smuggling is one of the main sources of revenue for organised crime, and on 28 April we adopted a new European Agenda for Security, disrupting the access of organised crime to revenue from various smuggling activities, including the cigarette trade, which is part of this fight.  Parliament has strongly supported lifting this fight to a global level. Why? Because cigarette smuggling is a global phenomenon and therefore it requires a global solution. What we now have is the Protocol to the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control and I am very pleased to inform you that on 4 May the Commission adopted a decision proposing that the Council ratify it.  We do recognise, however, that ratification will take time. So far, out of the minimum requirement of 40 ratifications for the Protocol to enter into force we only have seven. In addition, even if we are to reach the 40 ratification requirement, we do not yet know whether the key sources and transit countries will actually sign up to the Protocol. I can assure you that we in the Commission take very seriously our role of encouraging exactly those countries to be amongst those ratifying in a timely manner.  We are also advancing a timely implementation of the Tobacco Products Directive. However, this Directive cannot play an effective role in controlling cigarette smuggling from outside the EU. It is in this context of the limitations, at this moment in time, on what we would like to pursue as the long-term solution that we are looking at other instruments at our disposal. One such instrument can also be the anti-fraud agreements with the major tobacco companies.  As I mentioned, the first was signed in 2004. It was with Philip Morris International (PMI). It will expire in July 2016. This agreement introduced innovative concepts like track and trace, due diligence – you need to know to whom you sell, you also have to make that information accessible – and anti-money laundering provisions. PMI agreed to pay USD 1.25 billion, of which slightly more than 90 % – 90.3 % – went to our Member States.  The agreement is legally binding and enforceable. Its contractual nature allows for elements to be included which would not have been easily available by legislative means, and in particular seizure payments without proof of fault. They offer an additional financial incentive to compliance. My predecessor, former Commissioner Šemeta, has already informed Parliament that we had brief exploratory meetings with PMI as required by the agreement, at which point PMI expressed interest in discussing a prolongation. We are also analysing the situation in light of evolving trends in illicit trade. We know that the cheap whites are our biggest threat now, not those that come from these big companies, and we are also looking at how the development in the regulatory landscape which I have already mentioned would impact our judgement on how to approach the future of this agreement. We are going to finalise an assessment in a couple of weeks and, of course, we will make it available to Parliament and the public. There are some facts that are very clear: that the main objective of the PMI agreement – to reduce the presence of smuggled PMI products on the EU black market – has been achieved. Between 2006 and 2014 the volume of illegal PMI products seized by Member States under the agreement dropped by 85% and that substantially exceeds the overall downward trend in seizures. This drop applies equally to both genuine and counterfeit PMI products. We are currently considering the next steps forward in this dossier, guided by our commitment to fight the illicit trade and serve the interests of our citizens. I want to state very clearly that we are very open on how we are going to end this, and in this sense my being here with you this evening is very important as an input that you will provide in our deliberations. I will keep you duly informed as we progress on this very important and very sensitive topic. I would like to end by thanking the Greens for their initiative, including Mr Geier, who I know is very interested in this matter. Actually, I realise he is not a Green but would like to thank him for his interest, for which I am very grateful.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for doing what obviously at the moment seems possible for her to do. It is greatly appreciated that she has come to Parliament with a statement on the cooperation agreements between the Member States, the European Union and the major tobacco companies.  However, it is our view that the negotiations between the Commission and the tobacco companies should be much more open and transparent. As it stands now, we have been allowed to view the documents in a secure reading room for a couple of hours, and this took place after a rather frustrating correspondence with her predecessor. As a matter of fact, it would require a specialist lawyer to understand anything that is in those papers. We are now anxiously waiting for the Commission’s assessment of the benefits of the current tobacco agreements, or agreement with Philip Morris International, within the next couple of weeks, as was mentioned. But I think we should go further. It is now essential for the way negotiations are conducted to be changed. This Parliament should, at the least, be informed of the discussions along the way, and not after everything has been said and done. Even better would be to invite us to the table as observers to monitor the reasoning of whether it would be good to prolong the agreements, for what reasons, and what we, as the Union, could achieve by prolonging these agreements. It is about taxpayers’ money, and at the moment there is a feeling among the public that they are being held as mere bystanders in what is potentially of huge importance financially and otherwise to them, as citizens of the Union. After all, how are taxpayers supposed to be represented if Parliament is not properly and entirely informed?

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her long meeting behind closed doors with the coordinators and Members of our committee, and also for their presence today to follow this debate. We are in the field of combating the illicit trade in tobacco, smuggling and counterfeiting, a phenomenon which, as has rightly been raised, losses in national and European budgets of more than 10 billion per year. It also funds, when we fail to control it, criminal activities of all kinds and affects, of no other way, health, especially when it is uncontrolled. When we do not control its components, the product is also lowered on the market – because it is smuggled and counterfeit – and creates situations of uncontrollability and risk to our citizens in the context of this crisis. The agreements have generated and pooled resources and coordination to combat this smuggling on a global scale; therefore, in our group, for the new agreements that may be con reached — if so, since it is not yet decided — we want, in any case, to shed light on the results of what has already been done, with its pros and cons, to see whether or not they can really be useful in avoiding major ills and , in the area of budgetary control, also to establish as much control as possible in terms of criteria and conditions. As a Parliament, we want the fight against smuggling, illegal trade and counterfeiting of tobacco to remain at the most effective level; on the global level, it has to be like this. But as a group we also want to be able to follow step by step the Commission's dialogue with tobacco companies, as required by the Agreement and, above all, we want our opinion to dismiss all growing risks and avoid maximalist positions that cause greater ills.  We don't want to see again on the market, let alone in times of crisis, uncontrolled cigarettes of any kind. We are therefore left with the commitment you have just offered us: to see each other again once you have this report so that we can first form our opinion — we owe it to our citizens — which must have as its ultimate objective to preserve health, not only physical health , too and above all – but also the economic health of both the Member States and the European Union.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: on the alde group. – Mr President, Commissioner, today's issue is a sector that is very sensitive, even controversial, and that is also the regulatory rules attached to it. On the one hand, especially in the last period, there is no general societal demand for the sector to grow and therefore access to it is mostly restrictive, coupled with an effort to cover the negative externalities associated with the pernicious impact on the health of the population. On the other hand, we attach some legitimacy to the sector and, once the conditions of controlled restriction have been met, we expect it to comply with the usual market rules, especially free competition. Moreover, the sector is the bearer of considerable sources of income in public finances. Combining these three points of view into one regulatory framework is not easy. At present, regulatory rules take a form in place that essentially meets the current societal need. However, they are not error-free and some parametric changes are required to enhance their functionality. In particular, the following three amendments can be mentioned: firstly, the setting up of a fair and transparent way of distributing funds obtained on the basis of fines collected from key tobacco producers. Secondly, enhancing the transparency and alignment of agreements concluded between the Commission and the four main producers, taking into account their content and time validity. It is legitimate to ask whether these four agreements have a real ability to minimise the problem and why they have different validity periods. There should also be information on their basic points. So we demand openness from you, Commissioner.  Thirdly, unfair manifestations of cigarette trafficking relate to other developments which are not affected at all by these agreements and, for some Member States, constitute a major market destruction, namely the influx of cigarettes of usually low quality, sold outside official markets and imported from third countries, particularly in the peripheral border regions of the European Union. Restrictions on these transactions are equally necessary, as their effects may be even more pernicious than in previous cases. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: blue-card question. – Mr President, I listened quite carefully to the explanation by my colleague, but my question is rather of a general nature. When we are talking about this battle, as the Commissioner has pointed out already, it is about money, nothing else: money from the point of view of the governments; and money from the point of view of the criminals. Does she think that the current policies of the European Commission are adequate in order to prevent future crimes?

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr Colleague, as you rightly mentioned, the policy is not adequate at the moment and I have mentioned that parametric changes are necessary. I mentioned at random only three that I see as important. But of course we could talk more about the changes if we had more than two minutes of time. So I am in a mood to make sure that changes are included in other policies.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Thank you to the Commissioner for her statement. I think we all share the view that cigarette smuggling and counterfeit cigarettes need to be tackled. The problem is that the cooperation with the cigarette manufacturers originally resulted from a legal settlement. We have now gone many years and it has now become clear that the tobacco industry is continuing its lobby, including against the tobacco directive. That a trial is even being initiated against the European Commission over the tobacco directive.  They're not exactly friendly guys, I'd say. They are also no longer boys that the international community, with the World Health Organisation at the forefront, thinks you should treat them like ordinary other lobbyists or companies. We have strict rules: if I receive a lobbyist from the tobacco industry in my office, I have to tell not only that I have had that contact, but also exactly what it was about, what material I received. In fact, we are now asking the Commission exactly the same thing. You have contacts with the tobacco industry - extremely sensitive - and you are obliged to give us all the material, not just us parliamentarians, but the people, that the tobacco industry gives you. I would like to see the Commissioner's commitment that the People of Europe will receive this material.

name: Bart STAES
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – The tobacco agreements with Philip Morris are seen as an important element in the fight against tobacco smuggling. But despite this agreement and also the agreements with many other tobacco giants, such as Japan Tobacco, British American Tobacco and Imperial Tobacco Limited, smuggling still causes a yearly shortage of revenue, excise duties and VAT of some EUR 10 billion. That sum is obviously not going down, because I've been hearing that sum of 10 billion for years. In Parliament, as you know it, there are more and more critical voices on this agreement. The Dalli case is no stranger to that. Nor is the case of the former top civil servant Michel Petite, who has become a consultant in a law firm working for PMI, any such issue. The difficult debate and lobbying around the creation of the tobacco directive is no stranger to this. And so we in this House are demanding a general transparency of all the documents available on these tobacco agreements. As Mr Sarvamaa has already said, the way in which we must deal with this now is absolutely inadequate. We are asking ourselves a lot of questions about these agreements. After all, is it normal for us to start negotiations or talks with PMI, which at the same time is a company that is suing the European Union for the sake of the tobacco directive? That seems very strange to me. Moreover, is it in accordance with Article 5.3 of the World Health Organisation framework agreement that we simply have conversations with PMI? These are the questions we are asking on top of whether these agreements are really useful.  You've announced an evaluation. I am really curious what will be in it. A hearing here in the European Parliament has ensured that [the President deprives speaker of the floor].

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the citizens of Europe do not know that the Member States have received EUR 2 billion over the last 10 years from tobacco companies in order to combat cigarette smuggling. Nor do they know that a large proportion of smuggled cigarettes come directly from tobacco companies. And they do not know that in 2000 the European Commission brought several legal actions against Philip Morris, which were abandoned in 2004 after Philip Morris agreed to hand over a billion euros over 12 years to Europe. Above all, however, they do not know – and we do not know this in this House either – how the Member States actually spent this money.  One thing we are well aware of is that tobacco smoke is the second leading cause of death in the world and the leading cause of avoidable death. Smoking causes more than 80 000 deaths in Italy and 5.4 million deaths worldwide every year. To be mischievous, one might think that the Member States and the Commission accept the money of the tobacco companies to allow them to continue selling smoke. Where and how was this money spent?

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on smuggling, trafficking is a direct consequence of European policy. This widespread traffic is made possible by Schengen, and in particular by the abolition of internal customs. Schengen is the explosion of tobacco trafficking. So you are directly responsible for this situation.  Some want a Schengen, a Schengen I, a Schengen II, especially in France, like Nicolas Sarkozy. Today, for my part, if we want to stop traffic directly, we must once and for all put an end to Schengen and we must not have Schengen I or Schengen II. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Andreas SCHWAB
