text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Ferrand, do you know – having referred to Schengen since you have said this – that cigarette smuggling relates to the free movement of goods, but Schengen to the free movement of persons? Perhaps you have confused a little.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: "blue card" answer. "Dear Colleague, there is no confusion, I believe that today, until the principle of a domestic policy is put in place, so that States themselves take back their own security and their police, we will never be able to put an end to trafficking. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, dear colleague, you have mentioned Schengen - and it has just been clarified that this is not exactly the area of competence of Schengen - but there is one country, the United Kingdom, which is not in Schengen. Do you believe that there is no trafficking of cigarettes in the British area, when that country is not a member of Schengen? Do you not find that there is an inconsistency in what you say?

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, Mr Lavrilleux, we are not going to make history again. If you are in favour, precisely, of a Europe that removes all its legal means of controlling both tobacco trafficking and all other trafficking, especially the problem that is happening in the Mediterranean... I think it is still not understood that guaranteeing the sovereignty of states means putting in place a new policy that aims, precisely, to strengthen states.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Mr President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Today's debate is, after all, a flight forward. I very much welcome the fact that the Commission is finally speaking out publicly after all the secrecy we have experienced on this issue for almost two or three years. To date, a crucial question remains unanswered, namely: what results has the agreement to date yielded? How have these agreements curbed smuggling with their own products? I would like to say that these agreements are not anti-fraud agreements. The question of what they are then is an important question. The documents we have seen, which I have seen, still show major gaps in the tobacco supply chain, and the systems are far from fraud-proof. Nor could I see that OLAF actually exerted pressure to change that. I was amazed by the donkey patience with which the office has proceeded, almost the lack of interest. Especially since the Office is no longer present at all in important places of cigarette smuggling – and you rightly pointed out that cheap whites are the bigger problem for us – namely in Kaliningrad or in China. With the debate with my National Front colleague, I really want to say that if Schengen had anything to do with it, or the EU, then we would not really have a problem with many places in the world. I would like to insist on the publication of all documents that do not concern trade secrets regarding track and trace or know your customer. These are extremely important stories in order to be able to evaluate the tobacco agreements. What we should publish are the reasonable expectations of tobacco companies, these are letters. We should have the annual additional seizure payments and, of course, all statistical documents, because here too I cannot identify any trade secrets. And, of course, all OLAF's contacts with the tobacco industry should also be disclosed. Thanks to the agreements, the tobacco industry has a place at the negotiating table, and this too should be said frankly, namely that these agreements make this industry fit for the court, including in cooperation with the Member States. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: blue card question. – Mr President, I wanted to better understand some of Mrs Grule's reasoning, because I too have seen the documents and it is true that one thing is what OLAF finds, as we see that it is continually finding – certainly in my country, thousands and millions of boxes – and another thing is the documents where they appear. For once, my country has ratified the protocol to eliminate illegal trade in tobacco products under the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. Instead, his Government has not ratified it. I would like to ask Mrs Grule: why do you think your Government has not ratified this protocol? Why don't you care or because there are other topics? I say this so that we can better understand what designs we have, the expectations we have in relation to these agreements.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Madam President, then just ask my government. I am here as a member of the European Parliament and not as a spokesperson for the German Federal Government.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: – Mr President, I certainly welcome the four agreements between the EU Member States and the four tobacco companies. These are used to tackle illicit trade in tobacco and cigarettes and, of course, they actually benefit the tobacco companies as well because, without these agreements, these tobacco companies would be losing revenue, so there is an incentive for them to sign these agreements.  But this is also important for the EU and our Member States so that we can reduce the amount lost in customs and excise duties, and there are also the funds which are provided by the tobacco companies, as part of the agreement, to the EU and to Member States. Therefore, I would hope that the existing agreements will continue and those which are due to expire will be renewed as soon as possible. I would also say that we should not forget the health and security dimension of these agreements. It is important to restrict large amounts of cheap tobacco from coming onto the market for health reasons. It is also important to stop income from tobacco smuggling going to terrorist groups inside and outside of the European Union. So in view of that I would support us asking the Commissioner to produce an assessment of the effectiveness of the current arrangements, if not this month then hopefully at the June plenary session, and I am pleased that she did indicate in her contribution that that might be possible. Finally, I would also hope that Member States sign the protocol to eliminate illicit trade in tobacco products and cigarettes. I think this is important. This will allow us to tackle the problem not just inside the European Union but also the illicit trade coming to the European Union from outside. So I would urge Member States to ratify that particular protocol as soon as possible. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Nathan GILL
text: blue-card question. – Mr Vaughan, my colleague from Wales, do you accept that Welsh consumers are being served best by plain-paper packaging and open borders that allow smugglers easy access throughout Europe? Granted, we do have a closed border in the UK because we are an island, but it is much easier for smugglers to get their products onto the borders of the UK. Do you think that Welsh consumers are being served best by these policies?

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for the question, my Welsh colleague. As other speakers have said, the UK is not part of the Schengen Agreement and I know, as you know, because we travel on a regular basis, that border control is quite strictly observed at UK airports and ferries. So it is much more difficult to smuggle anything into the UK. But what we are talking about here is an agreement with tobacco companies to make it even more difficult in the future for anybody – those inside the EU and those outside the EU – who want to bring these illicit goods into the European Union.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Mr President, with twelve years of hindsight, there is a lesson to be learned from the cooperation agreement reached in 2004 between the Commission and Philip Morris, compromise with the tobacco giants is probably not possible. So, to the credit of this agreement, the Commission is putting forward a reduction in the illegal trade in cigarettes, as we have heard, but the health experts, whom I read and listen to, say exactly the opposite and point out that in 2012, the big four tobacco companies paid about 4 million euros, or junk, only 0.5% of the total estimate of sales of contraband cigarettes. On the very principle of this agreement, the Commission tells us that, legally, everything would be in order. I will tell you that, ethically and politically, not everything is for us. This agreement is at odds, in particular, with Article 5, paragraph 3, of the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, which imposes absolute transparency, as has been said, on the direct links between policy makers and the tobacco industry, a guideline which we have applied scrupulously and to the letter, the rapporteur, Mrs McAvan, and myself, as rapporteur on the tobacco product directive. I conclude, Mr President, and I ask the Vice-President: there is still time to do the same thing, namely, to give up renewing this agreement and to invest in all the tools, considerably more effective, that she mentioned earlier.

name: José BOVÉ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I am simply repeating principle 1 of the World Health Organization protocol that there is an irreconcilable and fundamental conflict between the interests of the tobacco industries and those of public health policies. Article 17, point (c) of this convention makes it clear that stakeholders - and therefore the European Union - must reject all partnerships and agreements with tobacco manufacturers. I think it is legally clear: if we continue to negotiate, we are at odds with European law as well as with the international law we signed in 2004 and which came into force in 2005. So we have a legal reason to stop. Fraud and counterfeiting should not be confused. Fraud is organized by the tobacco industry, it allows it to earn money. Counterfeiting, on the other hand, causes him to lose money. That is why the tobacco industry is turning to the states and the European Union: to make money. Today, we must not support fraudsters, that is, we must not support the tobacco industry, which is a real mafia. So today I ask you very clearly to stop all negotiations with the tobacco industry. It is against the interest of public health and against the interest of international law. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, it seems that Mrs Ries does not want to answer questions because she does not have a very clear position, so I ask Mr Bové a question. Yes, you are right, we need transparency and documentation, but at the same time do you not believe that national police forces, police departments, interior ministries and customs police need to do their job? I have read a lot of articles and it seems that national police are tolerant of this trafficking in cigarettes. They have to do their job first.

name: José BOVÉ
text: "blue card" answer. "I agree with you, you have to do the job. But what about today's money that the Commission, which OLAF recovers, and which is sent back to the States? It is the tobacco manufacturers who carry out the checks in the states to verify counterfeiting, that is, it is the gangsters, the tobacco traffickers who themselves organize the fight against counterfeits on their own trafficking. It's still outrageous! Is it OLAF's role to do this work? No, that's not his role! In fact, we can see it today with the judge who must, at the level of Belgium, check where the Dalli case is. All OLAF employees have been summoned to verify illegal wiretapping. Today, OLAF is disqualified.

name: David COBURN
text: – Mr President, of course we all want to stop counterfeiting and the trade in illicit cigarettes but, while we have a complete open door policy across the whole of Europe, how on earth are we meant to check for quality and control for contraband? These agreements are nothing more than the EU putting a gun to the head of international tobacco companies to hand over billions of euros to the EU.  No wonder there is such an enormous trade in illegal goods. How does the EU propose to try to tackle the problem of counterfeit goods? It calls for plain packaging of cigarettes, which will be a counterfeiter’s dream! If the EU and the Tories have their way, standard plain packaging will make counterfeiting much easier by taking away all the complicated wrapping and markings that the tobacco companies put on their products to make sure they are of quality. There will be a flood of counterfeit goods coming into the EU. How on earth are we going to protect consumers? They want to smoke cigarettes. They do not want to smoke goodness knows what. They only want to smoke cigarettes. The EU negotiating important international agreements on taking large sums of cash to squander is completely undemocratic. This should be the province of the nation state and nothing to do with the EU. Through these agreements, the tobacco companies have committed to paying the EU collectively USD 2.15 billion. This is an EU protection racket worthy of the late Al Capone and another example of the dark and perverted science of the EU.

name: Claudia SCHMIDT
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. The tobacco agreements as they exist are supposedly a good thing. How good, however, we do not know, because the Commission cannot or does not want to tell us the results of its assessments, if they have already been completed at all. What we all know, however, is that the agreement with Philip Morris will expire in 2016. That is why I am asking my questions: where does the Commission see the added value of the annual payments if the funds are not paid to the Member States for a specific purpose? Have we already held initial talks with Philip Morris to discuss a possible extension of the agreements? If not, when will this happen? Why is time being wasted on a Eurobarometer survey on tobacco agreements, and what is the added value here? It is time for answers to be finally provided, because the questions are piling up and time is running out.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Mr President, Vice-President Georgieva, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. So I am a cheerful German Social Democrat, not a Green. When I have finished my speech, you will also see the difference between me and Mr Bové. Then, I believe, this will become a little clearer. I would like to draw attention to a point which has not yet played a role in the debate, which makes the fight against cigarette smuggling particularly important. Behind this are structures of organised crime. The stuff has to be introduced, it has to be distributed. The money collected in cash must be laundered, so the money must be returned to the money cycle. Cigarette smuggling, as is currently taking place in Europe, can only take place on the basis of organised crime. And this is a situation that undermines democracy and we cannot take it seriously enough. It is true that, in fact, the major dangers no longer come from the relevant cigarette brands, but the so-called cheap whites are now on the rise. In Berlin, for example, a brand that is not legally available at all in Germany now accounts for 25% of consumption. This also shows the extent to which this has taken place. The agreements are therefore certainly not the means of restricting smuggling, and we will have to do more to do so. It is also a question of the EU's commitment to ensure that EU representatives from OLAF also sit in key capitals of cigarette producing countries and contact the authorities there. I think this is particularly important, and it is really unacceptable that OLAF should only be represented in Kiev. This must be clearly developed. But the tobacco agreements are certainly a means of doing something else. I do not believe – as colleagues from the Greens and the Christian Democrat Group have called for – that we should stop the negotiations, not at all. What else should we do other than talk? We certainly cannot make any progress with appeals, so I am of a clear opinion: let them hit us where it hurts, namely with regard to money. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the "blue card" procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: José BOVÉ
text: "blue card" question. I intervened on the question of the difference between fraud and counterfeiting; the World Health Organization recognizes that fraud is organized, for example, by Philip Morris himself. It is very clear that the networks that arrive in Europe go directly through Russia, in particular, and now through other channels. It's a recognized fact. They organize the fraud themselves.  Today, however, it is counterfeiting that is hurting them because it causes them to lose money. That is where the scandal lies today. Do you understand the difference between the two when, in fact, WHO clearly recognizes Philip Morris' responsibility for organizing its own fraud?

name: Jens GEIER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. The difference is clear to me, of course. You only have to take note, Mr Bové, of the fact that the proportion of Philip Morris cigarettes in cigarettes that have been confiscated has now fallen by 85%. The statement you made about the situation, about the assessment of the World Health Organisation, may then be out of date, because the accusation that the tobacco industry itself supports the smugglers does not seem to be true for this company, at least then. I believe that this is a very direct result of the agreements, and that is why I support them.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I think that smoking is undoubtedly one of the most serious risks to the health of Europeans. Any step we can take to reduce this danger is therefore welcome. This also applies to the fight against the illicit trade in cigarettes and tobacco. As a result, not only do we lose billions of euros in customs duties and taxes every year, but we are opening up space for further negative social phenomena. In some Member States, cheap illegal cigarettes lead to greater youth dependence on tobacco. And it is young people who should be protected the most. It is clear that profits from the illegal trade in cigarettes also help to finance the activities of organised crime groups. Perhaps no one therefore doubts that the best way to pay due attention to this serious problem must be found. That is why the European Parliament welcomed the conclusion of the current agreements in 2004. I am afraid that we cannot be so positive about the European Commission's current lax approach and procedure. Unfortunately, at the moment, relevant information is not available, which I think is very important for the future of these agreements, which the European Parliament must very forcefully demand. Above all, we do not yet know whether the agreements met the expectations that we put into them all those years ago. Although the new negotiations with tobacco companies began a year ago, the Commission has so far been unable to provide us with any information on what the situation will look like from the middle of next year, when the existing contracts expire. In fact, we don't even know if working with tobacco companies is the right way to go. In my opinion, this approach by the European Commission is not a way of convincing Members and the public that it is the best way to combat illegal trade.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: – Mr President, in 2007 during the plenary debates the European Parliament praised the agreements signed between the Commission and Philip Morris, and generally the agreements with other tobacco producers were regarded as a success story. A lot has been achieved in combating illicit cigarette trade and smuggling, especially when we look back to the 1990s. However, the EU continues losing around EUR 10 billion annually, and the greatest influx of smuggled cigarettes comes through external EU borders, including in the Baltic region. Thus cigarette smuggling remains a very acute problem and further improvements are vitally required in this area. But in order to take a position on whether we should continue with such agreements with tobacco companies after 2016, we must have relevant information on what was achieved and what the shortcomings were under the current agreements.

name: Karl-Heinz FLORENZ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. I am a little surprised that you call the tobacco smugglers smugglers. Forgive me, for me, these are health and tax criminals. You will still understand it. I have been working with the honourable Members for 20 years now, we have just adopted the Tobacco Products Directive, and we are already in the process of drilling up the traceability criteria and giving companies opportunities for individual contracts again. That is exactly wrong. We must now finally do what we decided a year and a half ago, namely to develop traceability strategies. May I tell you one thing about this? The tobacco industry – the very one you mentioned from London – has a great interest in participating in this traceability system, and it is very interested in declaring as much contraband as possible and counterfeiting as little as possible. Because they have to pay for the counterfeits themselves and the contraband does not. That's how the system has been until now. This needs to be addressed. We can no longer explain to our children that such a system of free-buying is still possible in this century! So you are not giving so much gas in terms of the continuation of this treaty, but you are giving gas to clarify. My esteemed colleague, Mrs Gräßle, mentioned the details and I do not want to repeat them because they are so good.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: –   Mr President, these tobacco agreements are not perfect. They have been criticised across the House today, not least for the toothless provisions such as seizure-based payments and for initiating close collaboration between the industry and the EU – illustrated by the very difficult adoption of the Tobacco Products Directive and by the delaying tactics that we have seen sometimes at the very highest levels in the EU. That said, the agreements have contributed to addressing the issue of counterfeit cigarettes and the parallel market as part of the EU’s wider strategy to step up the fight against the illicit tobacco trade.  In the absence of plans for anything else, I believe that we should cautiously welcome their renewal, but I note that much more needs to be done. The best way of combating this sort of fraud is to stop demand in the first place. We should stop, as far as we can, people taking up this disgusting habit. So I would urge the Commission to make sure that implementation of the Tobacco Products Directive moves ahead swiftly and that swift transposition is encouraged.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. President, cigarettes and smoking pose a direct danger to human health, so we must be interested in strict control of the sector. And if we add to that the smuggling of cigarettes of dubious quality that cause significant revenue losses for the European Union and the Member States, from customs duties and taxes every year, then this is the argument for additional control.  This is about the health of our citizens that is at risk as well as the money of our taxpayers that is being lost, so we as their representatives need to have more information about the communication that is taking place between the Commission and the tobacco industry. Smuggling products charged with high taxes such as cigarettes and alcohol is a crime that very often occurs on the eastern borders of the European Union and can be linked to the growing poverty of the population there. It is therefore necessary, in my view, to pre-initiate economic activities that will provide legal revenues to the population and, on the other hand, to carry out targeted customs operations and focus attention on the fight against crime and corruption.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Dear Mr President, Dear Mrs Georgieva, over 10 billion euro each year. losses of the European Union from illegal imports of cigarettes. Strong safeguards against this illegal import must be sought because it includes unlicensed products. For this reason, such products also pose a potential danger to citizens' health. Illegal imports also carry social risk. It presupses unregulated employment relationships and puts workers in this grey sector at even greater risk. The nearly ten million cigarettes that are brought into my country Bulgaria daily and for which no taxes are paid are causing disproportionate economic harm. Various organizations estimate that my country suffers losses of at least $450 million. Lv. annual excise duty and VAT – an amount that exceeds the total cost of monthly child benefit and is tenfold more than the total cost of transporting students and free textbooks. For the sake of the cause to stop this practice, I believe that by renewing agreements with large tobacco producers, stronger mechanisms for more socially responsible control and transparency will be established.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Dear Mr President, Commissioner Georgieva, many critics have taken the tobacco agreements to this House today, clearly they are not perfect, but they are also necessary to protect the interests of manufacturers, as they should and to increase scrutiny of the implementation of these agreements. It is known that Bulgaria is a traditional manufacturer of tobacco and tobacco products. Tobacco production alone accounts for around 5.5% of agricultural workers and tobacco accounts for 13.8% of agricultural exports. Estimates show that tobacco provides work and income to about 35,000 farms. The industry is extremely important for a number of regions in Bulgaria and is the only livelihood in some municipalities. Therefore, any restrictive measures against producers and the sector would have serious negative effects. At the same time, smuggling and counterfeit producers inflict serious financial losses on Bulgarian producers. I therefore support the idea that the Commission should consider tightening scrutiny of compliance with these agreements and try to stop smuggling.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Madam Commissioner, Mr. President, if this agreement is going to resolve the issue of smuggling and fraud, then it is welcome. If this agreement is going to resolve the issue of losing 10 billion euros in budgets, then it is welcome.  However, here as you can see, there are a number of doubts that this will be resolved so easily. Because of all the actors who are extremely interested in this story. I would like to take this opportunity to ask you to pay attention not only to large tobacco manufacturers, but also to protect in some way smaller tobacco and cigarette manufacturers (if you can say so) because this work is also very important for the country from which I come. Croatia has significant production of tobacco and cigarettes. In this context, I think it's important for them to be involved.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, there are undoubtedly unclarified aspects of these agreements between the European Commission and the tobacco industry, as there are also aspects to be clarified in relation to the very substantiation of these agreements, tobacco smuggling and smuggling. Because they are not independent laboratories but the industry itself determining whether or not there is contrapartation, for example. The dynamics of this illicit business and its interpenetrations with the lawful part of the business undoubtedly deserve further further further clarification. We follow the question that has been raised here about the amounts and destination of the funds received by the Member States under this agreement. One thing is certain, it is a lot to do in the field of combating smoking. In Portugal, for example, in four years, the number of places with smoking cessation consultations has fallen by almost half. An enlightening example of who wins and who loses with the current state of things.

name: João FERREIRA
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank everyone for participating in a debate that clearly showed the complexity of the topic we are discussing today. I would like to apologise once again for mixing up people and parties. It was not intentional, and so I would also like to thank Mr Staes and Mr Geier for their contributions. Let me make five points today. This will be one step in an ongoing debate with the Parliament on this topic. My first point is that this House has my personal commitment on an engagement that allows us, together, to define what the role of this particular instrument is. As many have said, we need a broader approach that is not exhausted by this specific instrument, but we also have to decide on its role in the future. My second point is that in the differences in opinion, there was one issue on which almost everybody was of the same opinion – namely the necessity for more transparency so that, as we move forward, it is done in the form of an open discussion. Of course, to the extent that we can pursue transparency in that matter, we will do so. In other words, we are going to come to Parliament with ways in which Members’ participation in the deliberations can be active.  My third point is that there are no ongoing negotiations. None. There have been, as per the agreement, exploratory talks. These are required by the agreement with Philip Morris International. Two years before exploration, we need to look into the potential for prolongation. These talks have addressed one issue, namely whether there would be interest on the side of Philip Morris. They seem to be interested and we have also indicated on both sides that, before we move towards any step for or against negotiations, we need to complete our own assessments. Our assessment is ongoing. Once it is finalised, we will share it with Parliament. On that basis, we will make a decision on whether or not – of course, in consultation with the Council and Parliament – to go for a prolongation. Some of those here have spoken clearly in favour – some clearly, some cautiously, but saying that it is an instrument which still seems to be necessary – and there have been those speaking clearly against it. We obviously have to look at the costs and benefits before we come to any decision. That is something that we would do in an open and transparent manner. There will be no negotiations of which you are not aware, if at all, because that is – I repeat – an open question.  My fourth point is on a question that was posed to me, and I want to address it directly: does one have the right even to consider negotiations, given that the Protocol in relation to Article 5.3 of the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) calls on the parties to protect their public health policies from commercial or vested interests, and it actually says that you should not talk to these people or engage with them? This is the point that was made. I want to stress that the WHO Secretariat to the FCTC has issued guidelines on how they would wish to see that article implemented by the parties. These guidelines contain an explicit exemption for binding and enforceable agreements, such as these tobacco agreements. That is not to say that we should rush into a decision lightly, but rather that there is a clarifying document – the guidelines – that go with the Protocol. My fifth and last point is just a point of clarification on an independent laboratory. We agree that this is necessary. A number of Members pointed out the fact that, if the companies themselves are those who have the means to do all the assessments, then we are a bit blind. I confirm that we have taken a decision and we are pursuing having an independent laboratory that we can use.  With the assessment forthcoming, I just want to stress that there has been quite an impressive impact on reducing illicit trade. Just to give you a sense, we have had here a debate that has spread over about an hour and a half. In each minute of that hour and a half, 22 packs of illicit cigarettes have been seized. The volume is in the billions. These are cigarettes that are not put on our markets at a price below the regulatory one, are accessible to our young people, and are not in line with our health policies. This is taking money away from our treasuries. So there is clearly a benefit, but we also have to be mindful that we have an evolving regulatory context. I want to stress this. We now have the directive and we have the Protocol. We have to make every effort possible. I could not agree more with the speakers who have said that we should implement the directive and accelerate the ratification of the Protocol. That remains our bigger objective. The question we have to answer is whether there is a need, in the foreseeable future, for other instruments to complement these two big funding elements of what we want to use to fight smoking for health reasons and illegal trade for health, fiscal and security reasons. We will answer this question with the House, and with the help of its Members, for which I am very grateful.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: sit. – The debate has been closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. – The Commission is making a serious mistake by entertaining contacts with the tobacco industry to renew EU agreements. The initial agreements were born from a settlement to a case where the Commission accused three tobacco manufacturing giants of being part of a global scheme to smuggle cigarettes, launder the profits of narcotics, fix prices, bribe officials and conduct illegal trade with terrorist groups. Yet these companies have been put in charge of monitoring counterfeiting in tobacco smuggling seizures, paying the authorities whenever these are found to be genuine so, unsurprisingly, they have found only 0.5% of seized shipments in 2012 to be genuine. This is a mockery of enforcement and, what is worse, never has a sample been analysed by an independent laboratory, and we know very little of the specifics behind this scheme. The Commission was asked by the EP to conduct a proper assessment of this scheme back in 2012, and this is long overdue. What is more outrageous is that, while these talks are going on, these very same big tobacco companies are challenging the Tobacco Products Directive in the ECJ. Instead, we should be working on how to ratify and implement the WHO Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products, which the Commission rightly wants the Council to do.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. – Although the European Union has been trying to regulate the tobacco industry since the early 1990s, it must be noted that smokers in Europe are declining only very slowly. This is roughly 1 to 2% a year. I therefore welcome the European Commission's proposal for a new directive because I believe that we must strive to reduce smoking, especially among young people, and to meet the target of halve the number of young smokers by 2025. The vast majority of smokers start smoking at a very young age - 70% before the age of 18 and 94% at the age of 25, a Eurobarometer survey showed. Indeed, it is alarming that tobacco use in the European Union leads to around 700 000 preventable deaths per year in the European Union. On the other hand, however, there are the economic aspects of restricting the tobacco industry for the Member States of the European Union in the form of a reduction in revenue to the state budget from the tax on the sale of tobacco products and the loss of around 150 000 jobs in the European Union and a significant increase in the illegal trade in tobacco products. However, I also see positive effects, which should also bring savings of a not insignificant amount in the area of healthcare, for example.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. – Considering the fact that we do not have yet any other political mean to fight illicit trade in contraband and counterfeit cigarettes, I believe that the European Parliament should wait for the assessment on the true effectiveness of the agreements that the Commission has promised to publish in the next weeks, and then decide whether to start the negotiations for renewal in a transparent way for an adjustment of the agreements, or to nullify the agreements with the main tobacco companies.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. – Tobacco production in Europe plays an environmental and social role in an agricultural activity that remains relevant in some regions. Although European production represents only 3% of the world's total annually, it is therefore no less important for rural populations engaged in this activity and depend on it, for example in the Azores.  The issue of contrapartitution has associated various problems, from organized crime, financial issues and, above all, health issues. It is therefore essential to make every effort to contain this practice. Contrabetobacco products are free of any quality control and hygiene and their content and ingredients are ignored. The risk of such products to health can be fatal and such a risk is unaffordable in a society with the means we fortunately have. I congratulate the European Commission on its agreement to the World Health Organisation Protocol on the elimination of illicit trade in tobacco products and i call for no means to contribute to this objective.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. – The illicit trade in tobacco products is mainly the smuggling of original cigarettes, the production and sale of counterfeit cigarettes and production which exceeds demand on a given market. Illegal tobacco products can be far more harmful than legal products, as they are manufactured in unverified plants and imported into the EU, and ingredients can contain more nicotine, tar and carbon monoxide, sometimes even fragments of packaging and plastics. In addition, other forms of illegal trafficking in human beings, drugs and arms are also being financed through the smuggling of tobacco products, and the impact of measures to reduce the use of tobacco products, such as tobacco taxes, health warnings and legislation restricting young people's access to tobacco, is also diminishing.  As a result of illegal trade in tobacco products, the EU and the Member States lose more than EUR 10 billion per year, which they would otherwise receive in the form of customs duties, VAT and excise duties. In order to combat the illicit trade in tobacco products, they therefore signed tobacco agreements with four tobacco manufacturers. The question now arises as to whether existing agreements should be renewed or new. In order to answer this question, we should be aware of the commission's assessment of the implementation of existing agreements at Parliament's request and the assessment of the added value of tobacco agreements.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. The Member States have received EUR 2 billion over the last ten years from tobacco companies to combat cigarette smuggling. This enormous contribution stems from the agreements concluded following legal action taken by the European Commission against Philip Morris, which was abandoned in 2004 after Philip Morris agreed to give EUR 1 billion over 12 years to Europe. The other major tobacco companies subsequently entered into similar agreements. 90% of these funds have been distributed to the Member States, but the way in which they have actually used these funds remains unknown.  Smoking is the leading preventable cause of death in the EU and causes around 700 000 deaths every year. For the treatment of patients suffering from diseases attributable to tobacco smoke, hospital expenditure amounts to about 3.4 billion euros, while the total health expenditure is more than 7.5 billion euros. The Commission does not yet know whether it will renew these agreements. Where has this money been spent? What action have the Member States taken to prevent the movement of contraband and counterfeit products? How many cigarettes were seized coming directly from the manufacturers?

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the Commission statement on VAT rules and mini one-stop shop for VAT for digital services, books and newspapers in the EU (2015/2682(SR)).

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like first of all to state that the Commission has already started to explore ways to implement the definitive VAT regime. This regime should be based on the principle of taxation at the place of destination. Reviewing the scope of the application of reduced rates is part of this exercise.  In general, it is important that the VAT system be applied fairly and efficiently, without giving any sector or any business an advantage, nor inviting the relocation of activities within the EU based on VAT rules. The Commission intends to communicate its vision of the main features of a future definitive VAT regime next year. The current tax treatment of e—services, such as digital books and the digital press, will be reviewed in this framework. I would personally support an initiative for reduced rates on e—books and the digital press.  On the taxation of the digital economy, I am also fully aware of the complaints which we have received, mainly from the United Kingdom, on the impact of the new 2015 VAT rules on microbusinesses. In the digital single market strategy, the Commission will come up with proposals in 2016 to reduce the administrative burden on businesses relating to VAT; the extension of the current single electronic registration and payment mechanism to intra-EU and third country on-line sales of tangible goods; the introduction of an EU-wide simplification measure in the form of a VAT threshold to help small start-up e-commerce businesses; and the possibility to carry out so-called home country controls, which means a single VAT audit framework for cross-border businesses.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Vice-President, first of all, thank you for being here tonight. I would like to quote very briefly from a 2013 European Parliament resolution on the completion of the Digital Single Market. We have already expressly stressed in paragraph 51 that it is important to ensure that consumers do not encounter obstacles if they want to purchase electronic books across borders, platforms or devices. To date, the European Commission has not delivered much on this. Your comments, Mr Vice-President, have not reinforced the impression that you are on the verge of taking appropriate action. It is obvious, Mr Vice-President, that the reader of a book must pay the same VAT rate for this service, whether he is using it as a hard copy or as a digital service. It is simply not possible to explain why two different VAT rates are to be charged for this. That is why, on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I would like to make it quite clear that we should start as quickly as possible by examining the judgment that was given against France and Luxembourg in the light of equal treatment for comparable services in the European internal market and to move forward as soon as possible with a change in the VAT directive with a view to uniform taxation in the digital single market. Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the Secondly, time is short, and I would like to come to the second point: not only is there a uniformity of taxation of various services, or, in the case, now necessary for a corresponding hard copy, but we must also urgently look for simplification opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises, which are supposed to develop their home market in this digital internal market. That is why, in the digital age, I very much welcome the one stop shop for smaller companies in particular. Mr Vice-President, I would like to say to you that the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats will be on your side when it comes to negotiating with the 28 Member States what we can do to make these facilitations reach small and medium-sized enterprises in the end.

name: Neena GILL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, Commissioner Ansip acknowledges that by creating a connected digital single market, we can generate up to EUR 250 billion of additional growth in Europe, thereby creating hundreds and thousands of new jobs and a vibrant knowledge-based society. But Commissioner, to achieve this we do need several regulatory reforms and one of these is the tax treatment of digital products. I do support the need for alignment of VAT rates to ensure we have a level playing field and to eliminate distortion of competition, and tackling VAT fraud should remain a priority, but it is important not to forget the proportionality principle. So when on 1 January 2015 the new VAT rules on digital products sold in the EU came into force, which means that they are chargeable in the place of purchase rather than the place of supply, this resulted in many EU businesses having to register an account for VAT in every single Member State. I have been contacted by many new—tech SMEs which have been adversely affected and are on the point of closing down. So we do need to address this issue.  For example, in the UK, there are about 240 000 designers of knitting and sewing patterns which are sold as PDF downloads. They are struggling in terms of the cost of compliance, especially if they trade across borders. They face something like EUR 5 000 annually for each Member State. So I am not sure how we are going to achieve the digital single market if we have regulations like this. European SMEs also face distortions from VAT-free goods supplied by non-EU businesses.  So I welcome what you have said in terms of introducing legislation and simplifying measures, but I do think it is important that we get the right level of threshold that enables a higher number of digital start-ups, and that means exemptions for them.  There are some important issues, Commissioner, that you do have to address. How are you going to achieve a threshold given that you need the agreement of 28 Member States? Secondly, what will the level of the threshold be? In the UK, it is GBP 81 000, but I think we may need to go lower if we are to achieve our ambitions.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like you all to imagine for a moment that you have just set up a small digital business. Perhaps you sell e—books or knitting patterns online. You have heard about the digital single market, and you are excited to think that you can sell to customers not only in your own country, but across the whole EU. You know that you need to register for VAT but when you look into it, you find that you need to keep accounts for up to 10 years and calculate up to 88 different VAT rates set by the countries you sell to. Someone tells you that you can automate the process, but you find the system either does not work, or that you have to sell through an online marketplace that charges you a large fee and may interrupt your sales process to sell other products to your customers.  So what do you do? Do you feel inspired by this new digital single market, or do you give up and shut up shop? Well, EU VAT Action and Enterprise Nation, who represent digital entrepreneurs, tell me that thousands of their members are closing down. So while the Commission champions the digital single market, EU rules since January 2015 are strangling digital businesses to death with red tape.  Now we all know that these rules are well-meaning and introduced to tackle abuses by multinational companies, so why do we not introduce a threshold – or even an exemption – a limit below which digital entrepreneurs could continue as before, and then when their businesses grow larger, bring them into this new system? Let us not forget that every large business started as a small business. Most great entrepreneurs started with nothing. So if the EU is to be a place for aspiration and opportunity and we are to create this digital single market, then we need to help them. Let us listen to the digital entrepreneurs asking for our help. Let us introduce a threshold or an exemption to save their micro-businesses. Let us cut the red tape to make the digital single market a reality for them.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I think it is a good sign that we are having this debate with the Commissioner in charge of the digital market, although I am wondering who is really in charge, because I would say that this is a taxation matter.  I have been doing a bit of digging, and sometimes that gives you funny results. For example, Commissioner, one of the first questions relating to the application of the higher VAT rate to e-books was introduced by Mrs Thyssen, who was then a Member of Parliament and who is now actually your colleague. Mrs Thyssen was very worried about the higher VAT rates on, I quote, ʽbooks published on CD-Rom or DVDʼ. Now that was in 2009 – the Commission has not even started to think about solutions but CD-Roms are no longer used for e-books.  So the key words here are speed and urgency. Because I have also submitted a series of questions over the years, and in the answer to one of my questions in 2013 the Commission replied that it ʽis currently examining this issueʼ – blah di blah di blah – ʽand these elements will be taken on board in completing the impact...ʼ. In other words, already back in 2013 the Commission was looking into it.  So what are you waiting for? The digital market, as you well know Commissioner, is developing much more rapidly than this. We are legislating at Flintstone speed but the digital market is moving on. It is not waiting for us, and if you say 2016, well by then so many small businesses will have gone down already because they cannot survive.  Why does the Commission have to wait until 2016? Why cannot you just start tomorrow? If, Commissioner, you go back to the Commission and to the Member States and tell them that we need action now, I think that the whole Parliament will back you up because everybody here is echoing the same message. So I would say, Commissioner, let us get to work tomorrow.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the new rules on VAT, as other speakers have said, are obviously designed with positive intentions, but in fact if they are implemented as proposed they could have serious harmful and destructive effects on small businesses and sole traders. The Commission contends that the rules will introduce a level playing field, as they mean that sellers will not be in a position to undercut competitors unfairly by using a lower VAT rate. However, because there is no threshold, the real impact is that the smallest companies and sole traders are going to be left unable to compete and they are going to face the stark reality of having to close their businesses down in some instances. Moreover, it creates a divide between multinational companies, who can very easily put in place systems to comply with the new rules, and those small traders and small businesses that simply cannot do so. Small and medium enterprises, as you are well aware, Commissioner, are the lifeblood of many local domestic economies including my own, and they cannot be disregarded when we are introducing measures such as this.

name: Helga TRÜPEL
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has There are many good cultural policy reasons why there is a reduced VAT rate for printed books, printed newspapers, and printed magazines. That is why it is right to say when it comes to digital services – the e-books, e-papers and e-magazines – that it is also right that the reduced VAT rate applies to these products. When one thinks of the UNESCO Convention for the Protection of Cultural Diversity, it is stated that cultural goods are never just goods like others, but carriers of meaning and importance and can therefore also be regulated differently. Now, however, I do not want to hide the fact that, of course, there is also a very different debate, namely that there are now too many exemptions from VAT and that there are good reasons to achieve greater unification here in order to contribute to greater justice and clearer rules. But I would like to stress once again that as long as there is a reduced VAT rate for printed books and newspapers, this must also apply to the digital world, to digital services such as e-books, e-papers and e-magazines. I also believe that the Commission must act very quickly in this matter. We have no time to lose, but there is an urgent need for action here. That is why I would like to ask you to act quickly and not allow any more time to pass!

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Ansip, we listened to you with pleasure last week in Brussels. We believe that the digital single market will not flourish unless the VAT rates applied to goods and services purchased on the web are made homogeneous.  We are therefore in favour of a reduced VAT rate for digital goods and services such as e-books as early as 2015, therefore, the European VAT Directive. We think it is right that, as is currently the case, VAT on such purchases should be paid in the Member State of destination of the purchaser, but we also believe that this rate must be uniform throughout the Territory of the European Union.  The latter is a necessary condition for the rapid elimination of problematic geoblocking, so some content is available in some Member States and in others it is not. Geoblocking, as things stand at present, is the only way in which some companies, especially smaller ones, medium-sized enterprises and start-ups, can avoid dealing with 28 different VAT systems. Today's debate is an opportunity to highlight the urgent need to move towards a reduced uniform rate as soon as possible, therefore, for digital services, e-books, books and newspapers. This would be an immediate advantage for businesses and citizens and would accelerate the long and complex path that has just begun towards the digital single market.  We hope that no more valuable time will be wasted. Many European companies are failing in favour of non-European competitors.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: Mr President, new technologies are unquestionably a democratic means of enabling everyone to have equal access to culture and information. Nevertheless, this observation should not obscure the real problem which is the constant decline in reading in Europe. This issue of reviving reading is taking its place in this debate, but I remain convinced that the reduction of VAT for e-books is not the appropriate solution to the problem posed. As such, the 2006/112/EC Directive, which states that reduced rates cannot be applied on digital services, must be maintained as it stands because a planned reduction in VAT in this sector will undermine a whole part of our economy, i.e. bookstores, particularly independent ones, and the indirect jobs that result from them, in printing and publishing. I have seen this recently in my country, France, with the liquidation of Chapter bookstores and the loss of more than 500 jobs. This reduced VAT rate only favours large US multinationals such as Amazon and Google, leaders in this digital market, which practice tax optimization in Europe and thus create unfair competition. The real questions we must ask ourselves today are simple: how can reading in Europe be revived? What means do we have to support our bookstores and sustain thousands of jobs? Finally, how can we effectively combat the tax evasion strategies of the large multinationals, which put the European Union in the situation of the one who suffers rather than in the situation of the one who acts?

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I have listened with interest to the Vice-President of the Commission and I want to say that I have always supported low and simple taxes.  The example of e-books, which we are debating here today, clearly shows that if the tax system is complex and has a number of exceptions, then there are interpretation problems. When these problems are eliminated by the judiciary and the court, absurd situations often occur. An example is the case of the relationship between printed books and e-books, where different mediums, different information carriers are taxed differently. I would like you, Vice-President of the Commission, to see this case as an example of how exceptions do not work and the complex tax system does not work. If you are talking about the Commission preparing a definitive VAT regime, then you should learn from this case. Because the problem, in my opinion, is not in the decision of the Court of Justice of the European Union. I've read the verdict, and I think the verdict is the right one. The problem is in the directive, which vaguely and vaguely regulates exceptions. We should therefore talk about if exceptions, as they are to be defined, and if so, to the smallest extent possible. I ask you to fix the problem and, like my colleagues, I appeal to support the digital market. I believe that the absurd situation where only a different medium brings double VAT on books, on the one hand printed books and on the other on e-books, should have long ago been taken away. Please remove this in order to develop the digital single market.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – Any measures and initiatives that unify, simplify and make tax practices within the EU more transparent are to be welcomed. And the fact that, as of this year, the rate of taxation of radio and audiovisual media services, telecommunications and electronically provided services to individuals is determined by the VAT rate on the consumer's individual residence. Well, this is of the utmost importance to my country, the Hungarian businesses, because so far they have been at a huge disadvantage, because they were only able to provide services at the highest VAT rate in the Union, i.e. 27%, and everyone else was, of course, cheaper than them. However, in addition to drawing attention to the issue of overtrawing in itself, there are two other things that are at risk here. Hopefully, a European tax union will solve all this, but until we get there, we are facing two dangers here. One is that the idea of a 'mini one-stop shop' seems very good, but it is important to pay attention here to the fact that individual operators do not, say, collect the highest national tax rate. This is important because, for some services, this does not make such a striking difference. It is also a way of distorting trade so that some operators only supply to one market or a few markets, where VAT is the lowest. I therefore ask that we consider a common VAT rate for the most European and borderless services.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. I can only very strongly support the calls for speed – we live in a time when, if Europe loses competition with the United States, with Asia, it is because it is slower. Slower than others. Indeed, we cannot wait until 2016 for the Commission's agenda and action programme. In this case, two good trends converge. New internet business, small businesses, economic creativity, something that needs to be particularly supported in Europe. On the other hand, the good of culture. The book is a cultural good, a specialist magazine is also a cultural good that requires preferential treatment, so I demand not only simplification of procedures, but also a decisive reduction in taxes. The European Commission should encourage Member States, through its decisions, to reduce the tax burden in this very creative and important industry.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Mr President, one of the key priorities of the Commission is the digital single market strategy. The VAT on e—books, I think, is an excellent example where we can show that we are committed to this agenda and that we are able to deliver without delay to our citizens. I do not see any reason why I should pay twice as much in taxes on e—books than on books in their physical form. The rise in the price of e—books was never intended. It was an unforeseen consequence, an error, and now is the time to fix it. We all speak about the urgency of this topic.  I am looking forward to your VAT proposal in 2016, but meanwhile here is one suggestion: why do you not propose an urgent single sentence amendment to the 2006 VAT Directive allowing digital books, newspapers and magazines the same reductions already allowed for their physical counterparts? It would only require three words to be added to the Annex to fix it. The words are: ‘physical or digital’. Let us solve this in the simplest and quickest way possible. Let us make this an example where Europe sees an error and fixes it; where Europe embraces our digital future.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Mr President, it seems a good idea that large companies are taxing VAT in the customer's country in order to avoid the tax evasion that many make through tax havens such as Luxembourg. What is not logical is to subject micro-enterprises and cooperatives to this unbearable administrative burden. If they were looking to protect the weakest, they have once again achieved the opposite: many micro-enterprises have had to shut down or stop selling in Europe while multinationals like Google have taken advantage of the circumstances to absorb the sales activity of small developers. The Commission now has little credibility in its efforts to combat tax evasion, especially when we know that its President actively collaborated for years to facilitate this task for large multinationals. As long as the European Union continues to tolerate the existence of tax havens within it, large enterprises will still be able to sink small ones and expose them to citizenship.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Commissioner Ansip for his attempts to build a digital single market, and in particular for his willingness to listen to the problems of the many small business people in the UK who have faced enormous difficulties with the shift in the VAT regime that came into force on 1 January. My understanding is that the Commission originally proposed a threshold for micro-businesses but that this was not taken up. I can only think that the digital economy has advanced rapidly since that time and that politicians had not managed to understand how it was changing. On the positive side it has been really inspiring to see the creative enterprise that has been flourishing in my constituency and the wonderful potential there is for the digital economy to help us to build cultural and social links between the countries of our Union. These businesses are often run by the very people we seek to encourage into starting small businesses, especially women and those living in rural communities. They are now selling songs and teaching materials, knitting patterns and recipes, to customers in countries they may never have visited. But these businesses are fundamentally threatened, as other speakers have said, by the ending of the VAT exemption. I know that many of these entrepreneurs are already closing down their export operations or sometimes their whole business because the VAT regime is just too onerous.  I know that Commissioner Ansip has heard their cry for help but I would like to ask him to act swiftly and decisively to support the small businesses of the UK and other countries affected.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I can only join those voices who express their satisfaction that the Digital Single Market Strategy and the huge involvement of President Ansip will probably lead to a solution to many problems during our term of office. One such challenge is that, according to all my observations and according to the Eurobarometer, especially small and medium-sized businesses complain about VAT.  Recently, I spoke to an entrepreneur who sells tailor-made shirts to 9 countries. It would have developed at a dizzying pace had it not been for the fact that VAT, in every other country, provides it with so many problems. I do not know if you are aware that traders who trade across borders account for more than 60 VAT regimes. Because not only VAT is different in every country, but every product is different.  In this way, we move on to the publication of books or other content, such as magazines, newspapers – on paper or in electronic form. This is another barrier for producers, for publishers and for authors, which does not increase the level of readership, another barrier that virtually all consumers in the Member States complain about, as well as those who trade in these books – and today it is no longer possible to separate paper content from electronic content. If we don't deal with this topic right away, there may soon be other media in the area that we're talking about. Content is important and it is important that a European can get to know this content as openly as possible. I therefore call once again: agreeing to a common VAT in the European Union, agreeing to this between Member States should be an absolute priority for us.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, if your predecessors had listened to this European Parliament, we would not be here. For many years, we have been calling for the VAT rate to be aligned between the paper book and the digital book. In the end, it took the condemnation of two Member States by the Court of Justice for this debate to reappear and to be put back in the spotlight within the college. We have to go all the way and we have to go fast because there is no reason that this divorce between the different technologies will serve those who want to share the culture and reading. But we also need to make sure that, fundamentally, this technological neutrality will be there. It seems to me that the Court of Justice should also take into account this desire expressed here by the legislator, especially when new cases are brought before it when we have not yet amended the VAT Directive. In this debate, I have heard some very confusing comments and I think we have to take stock. In the Digital Single Market, we also want this to be an opportunity for a serious overhaul of our tax practices. But just because we want a reduced VAT for e-books does not mean that we want to give up real taxation for the internet giants, who benefit from comparative advantages by practising tax dumping or tax optimization. Let's not mix up all the debates. Let us deal seriously with each of the subjects and here, Commissioner, we ask you to move quickly to uphold technological neutrality which enables, among other things, to contribute to the development of culture, reading, freedom of the press and the expansion of digital technology in Europe.

name: Vicky FORD
text: – Mr President, if our economies are to prosper and grow we must support small businesses and make sure that the market is fit for purpose in the digital age. The new rules for VAT collection in Europe do not do this. They might work for big businesses, but they have had a devastating impact on microbusinesses. Entrepreneurs have faced huge bureaucracy and costs just to collect taxes which sometimes add up to less than a euro. A recent survey of 2 000 small companies suggested that a quarter of firms are now blocking overseas sales, and one in five has stopped selling altogether. That means they are not earning any money, and the authorities are not collecting any tax at all. We have promised to change the way the EU makes laws. We need to sort this out, and it needs to be done quickly. I think the easiest solution is an exemption, through a threshold, for micro entities, but that needs unanimous support from finance ministers. So ministers, do not wait; next year is too late. Our entrepreneurs need us now.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Thank you, Commissioner Ansip, for wanting to overcome the injustices that we can see here on the table right now. At the same time, I find it surprising to hear that the European Parliament is suddenly talking with one strong voice when, at the same time, we know that in this House it is not always the case that the digital single market is being backed up. When we discuss other things that are equally important, such as getting VAT rates in order, which are about ensuring that we have net neutrality, when we want to make sure that we get rid of roaming charges, when we want to make sure that we change the copyright rules to make them better, more modern and promote enterprise throughout Europe, then there are still many in this House and certainly in the Member States who say : No, stop and pad! However, it would be welcome if, after this debate, we could work together in this House to create the digital single market, where we do not say no to any kind of change, but ask ourselves: why is the UNITED States better than us in the digital field, and what do we need to do to ensure that we are better than them? These are the questions that this House should ask itself above all.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: – Dear Mr President, Dear Vice-President of the European Commission, if you ask me which book I would like to end up on a desert island, I will very easily answer you – I want to go with my tablet from which I can read all my favorite books. Thanks to digitization, we can read everywhere, and moreover, think about reading in a new, even more pragmatic and endless way. Now it's important not just to read. Digital technologies have changed the reading process and it is important that we rediscover and not deprive ourselves of the unique chance we have thanks to digitisation. Part of it, for example, is easier access to cultural content, also enshrined in the European Commission's new Digital Single Market strategy. At the core of the digital project are consumers and businesses. In itself, the process of change, the transition to the Digital Single Market will boost not only the economy, but also cultural diversity, the whole European Treasury and new education. An important step towards fulfilling our commitment is the unification of VAT rules for books and digital services, which will create the necessary favourable environment for both entrepreneurial thinking and public inclusion in Europe and the solid self-esteem of citizens of our continent. This is also the prerequisite for working for lower VAT rates for both digital and printed books and publications in countries such as Bulgaria.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Commissioner Ansip. Just two weeks ago, he presented his long-awaited and much-hyped digital single market strategy. The proposals, 16 of which are to be delivered in the next five years, are a step in the right direction. But they are by no means a silver bullet. As we have heard this evening, not all proposed initiatives seem to be working for SMEs and micro businesses. In fact, my Labour colleagues and I have received, and keep receiving, hundreds of e—mails from our constituents saying that the changes introduced from 1 January 2015 on new place of supply VAT rules, as well as the abolition of the UK threshold, which was GBP 81 000 in sales per year before people and businesses were eligible to pay VAT, have caused more obstacles when selling abroad rather than helping to eliminate them. The Mini One-Stop Shop, the VAT MOSS, was set up in order to aid businesses when selling abroad. How can they adjust their prices accordingly if they do not know what the VAT regime is in the country they are selling to?  Commissioner, in your digital market strategy, there is a mention the Commission will make legislative proposals in 2016 to introduce a common EU-wide VAT threshold to help small businesses; but by the time it becomes law, we could well be in 2017 or 2018. What do we do to help businesses in the meantime? The current legislation was designed and agreed back in 2006. However, that is almost a decade ago. I was pleased to hear what you said about e-books and the treatment of e-books in relation to printed books. Currently, printed books have a special privilege and are taxed at a reduced rate between zero and 10% across the Union. E-books are considered a digital service, even if they are actually only a book in a different format, and they are taxed at a rate between 18% and 25% across the EU. So I welcome your comments, but I would like to see the proposals on that fairness between the virtual and non-virtual coming sooner rather than later, so that consumers across the EU can benefit from your action.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: – As the European Union, we want to give e-commerce every opportunity. Unfortunately, small players are buried under administrative burdens. That is why I am asking - it is clear that more people here in Parliament have this question - to pay attention to SMEs in adapting the existing legislation and to the new rules that the Commission will propose during this legislature.  Ladies and gentlemen, the system as it exists today for automated electronic services has certainly come with the best of intentions. Unfortunately, the consequences for the smaller companies are greatly underestimated. As rapporteur of the report on better regulation, I would therefore like to propose that a better impact assessment be carried out for the new proposals on online trade in goods.  99% of our European companies are SMEs. We must learn from the past and we must give our SMEs the opportunity to grow further. E-commerce in the European Union must be more than some of the major players that dominate the market. I have therefore won the proposal to extend the system to goods purchased online, but with due attention to SMEs and with as little administrative burden as possible.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: – Mr President, it is a pleasure to have the Commissioner and Vice—President here tonight. Commissioner, I am not sure if you are the right member of the Commission for this issue that we have with VAT. I can see the UK has a lot of problems with it; other countries are happy about the changes because smaller countries are sometimes at a disadvantage when there is competition in relation to taxation and VAT rates.  It is a very complex situation, and we tend to make things very complex in Europe, unfortunately. I would suggest something though, which is to change the name ‘e-book’ into simply ‘DC’ (digital content). We should just change it to DC because we no longer know what a book is or what it becomes, and once you open it up you have live content and you are doing something else with it. So let us start thinking ahead of the curve, forget the past and see where these things will be in the future. The future will be a digital content single market. We need to be proactive and not reactive. I know the Commissioner is himself, so I would say: be brave; make very simple decisions to simplify Europe – for businesses to understand how things work. Whatever the tax is, make it very easy so that they can pay it easily and not have to close down. That is all it is about. It is going to be difficult to agree on rates for all of us, but we can definitely make things very simple and understandable.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: – The Court of Justice of the European Union recently ruled that it allows Member States to reduce VAT on books stored in digital form. From now on, we might as well be happy, but solving the issue is not that simple. The first question immediately arises as to what this digital form is, what we consider to be part of this circle. Then we are no longer happy, because it turns out that only books that appear on physical media, on CD, on usb sticks. For example, books downloaded from the Internet are already considered a service. I'm afraid that any exceptions we create in this area will only complicate the system. However, it is not in our interest at all to go in the direction of simplification, because I think that all the speakers have said that it is in our common interest that our businesses, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, which are less capital-poor, have fewer opportunities and become competitive in this area. So we should create legislation so that we can support these businesses, which have suffered a significant competitive disadvantage in this area. At the same time, I would also like to draw attention to another aspect of the issue of VAT reduction: the fact that this is a budgetary issue, an issue within the competence of the Member States. We don't want to complicate things. Simplification, acceleration and the first step must be a very good piece of legislation that creates the framework for this.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I can only add my appreciation to what my fellow Members have already said about the Commission's openness in reiterating the public commitment made by President Juncker on the issue of VAT on digital products, as well as the statements made when he took office on other obstacles to the creation of the digital single market. But now we need to translate these commitments into real initiatives, and do so quickly. This is the message that this Parliament is unanimously sending to the Commission this evening, because the digital single market is the real challenge facing the European Union in the near future, perhaps only to the creation of the single market. Digital can be the key through which Europe regains competitiveness and innovation, but it also plays a central role in the world cultural sphere. We cannot think of working towards this goal unless we see effective actions to break down anachronistic barriers such as the permanence of a different VAT between a paperback and a digital book. This debate is fundamental for the European Union because we are not discussing a technical issue, but about culture, the future, the promotion and concrete implementation of unity in diversity, which is our DNA as European citizens. We look to the future but we are held back by laces and laces that belong to a bygone era and we have to cut them in order to move forward.
