In order to take the lead in this digital revolution that we are going through, the European Union must ensure that it has the right tools and has no brakes that slow down our path.  What we are talking about today is certainly an example and I hope that the Commission will be able to find the most suitable solutions quickly; Parliament will support this effort because getting closer to the citizens also involves these initiatives.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I think it is absolutely right what has been said here in terms of content, both in terms of easing the burden on SMEs, also on bureaucratic hurdles, as well as on simplifying e-commerce and making books – whether published in electronic or paper form – ultimately subject to the same tax rules. I believe that this is important and right. At the same time, however, I believe that it is necessary – as the European Court of Justice has pointed out – for the European states, the nation states, to continue to have fiscal sovereignty to determine what tax rules apply in their states. The Commission should also bear this in mind that not every sensible regulation must always be made at European level. Some things can remain meaningfully regulated in the nation states.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: – Mr President, I am happy that my Group succeeded in putting this important issue on the agenda. The Commission needs to act fast on this issue. As many colleagues have pointed out, the digital world moves very fast, so we do not have three years, or even one year, to wait for the rules in order to make them adapt to the digital age. I totally support the idea presented by my colleague Ms Charanzová about a simple solution to solve this issue. I also want to point out that while some argue that books on paper need the reduced rate because they wear out, it is not actually about the format. The reduced rate is needed to support the creation and writing of books, and also the reading of books. A book is a book in whatever format it is. Therefore, a proposal to adapt VAT rules to make them fit for the digital age could not come at a better moment.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Mr President, an important action in order to achieve a digital single market is to simplify VAT rules for digital goods and services in order to improve online access to them and allow fair competition. New changes to VAT rules for digital sales that entered into force this year were intended to prevent giant digital companies from being the only ones reaping the benefits of the digital single market.  However, the new rules could have counter-productive effects and unintended consequences. I am particularly referring to the micro—enterprises that actually make up the majority of the digital services. VAT regulations may become real obstacles for users and providers of services, especially for cross-border operations. The new provisions must not lead either to an increase in prices for the consumers or to extra costs which are an additional burden for businesses.  Therefore, Commissioner, it is imperative to report as soon as possible on the functioning of the new provisions in order to make eventual adjustments if needed. The introduction of the place-of-supply principle and the VAT mini one-stop shop should also lead to less regulatory burdens, better and more cost-effective digital services. Furthermore, Member States should enhance cooperation as regards the VAT rate applied to digital services, in order not to discriminate against consumers across the European Union who might find themselves in the position of paying significantly different prices for the same services.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I believe that the alignment of VAT rates on e-books and e-papers is a very important step to carry out, as it would apply the same lowered VAT deductions to these digital services as to physical books and papers, thereby creating an equal, level playing field and eliminating distortion of competition. The actual divergences between VAT rates on physical and digital products cannot be justified after the entry into force of new VAT rules on digital products sold in the EU, which are now chargeable in the place of purchase rather than in the place of supply. This regulation would also facilitate purchases for people who cannot afford to pay more for the same kind of books. In order to enable all Member States to benefit equally from the digital single market, the principle of taxation in the Member State where consumption takes place should apply in all cases.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. President, the current VAT legislation on digital services is evidence of a lack of vision and a long-term development strategy, and also a classic example of distortions of competition rules, as it puts printed books and their publishers in a better position than digital editions and the companies that sell them. It's a relic of some past times when digital was a thing of the future.  Today I guess it is clear to everyone that we live in a digital era and that digital services have become our everyday life, so their providers should not be in a subordinate position on the market.  If we want to create a digital single market and modernise our economies, I believe that we need to replace such bad regulations of the past as soon as possible with quality and unencumbered regulation of the present and future.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, can we imagine for a moment taxing a Picasso work differently depending on whether it is a magnificent ceramic, a superb collage or a remarkable canvas? The same must be true for another form of cultural property that is the book. If the paper book benefits from a reduced rate of VAT, it is because, when it was decided, digital did not exist. Believe me, just as television did not kill cinema, the digital book will not kill the paper book and therefore the booksellers. Commissioner, as you have heard, we are almost unanimous in calling for a reduced VAT rate for the digital book, so let us decide quickly.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Mr President, too often we hear that the VAT mini one-stop shop (MOSS) might be associated with the alleged negative influence of the new VAT regime in which taxes are paid according to the place of consumption rather than the registered office of the provider. But VAT MOSS is not the core of the problem that some companies claim to have. On the contrary, this is a solution which makes the life of companies easier: a company may register and settle its VAT in one country through one platform and while contacting only one administration instead of having to deal with 28 administrations.  It is, moreover, a solution that is optional for taxpayers; nobody is forced to use it. No better mechanism has been developed until now that makes the registration and settlement of VAT issues in trans-border transactions easier. Besides, VAT MOSS is only four months old and it is still being improved. The Commission has already started to assess the effectiveness of the VAT MOSS platform.  The new VAT rules may indeed be problematic for some companies. Let us emphasise however that the Directive on the Place of supply of services was approved by all Member States and this Parliament. Member States have had seven years to adapt to the new VAT rules.  I strongly urge the Commission to work on technical solutions to improve and facilitate the way SMEs can deal with the new VAT rules and the use of VAT MOSS. At the same time, I call on my colleagues in this House not to blame VAT MOSS, an instrument aimed strictly at making companies’ lives easier, for every difficulty they may face with the VAT regime.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – The debate on the problem of taxes on electronic magazines and books has been going on for a long time. A number of expert and interest groups have also given their opinion on this problem, and one highlighted, among other things, the following: in order to achieve blagosity in the economic, social and cultural spheres of all citizens of the European Union, access to information, whether in printed or electronic form, is crucial and meets the needs of citizens in the same way. However, the same way of meeting needs is the reason why it should decide that printed and electronic publications are treated in the same way in the tax area. Books are our great wealth. Despite forgetting about them today in the face of a flood of electronic media, they are the participants in our history. That's priceless. Access to these books in traditional or electronic form must also be granted to everyone today, and I see no reason why the tax rates for electronic and printed books would vary. It's not about content, it's a different form. Development is moving forward in all areas, and of course tax systems must adapt to this. Dear Sir... (microphone off speaker)

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I would like to point out that what we are discussing here is actually two things. One is the amount of the value added tax rate and the other is the way in which those taxes are charged. I think we can all agree that when it comes to the single market for services in the European Union, building this digital market also requires streamlining in the tax field. Entrepreneurs don't like it when their tax rules change too often, but in this case, change seems appropriate. It is logical that value added tax, which is the taxation of consumption, should be paid in the state where the service is consumed. The Czech Republic has approached this directive responsibly and has already established one place, it is one of the regional tax authorities, where 317 entities are already registered. I think that the Commissioner should have an overview of how registration is also progressing in other countries. As regards the level of the rate, the Commission should certainly act in agreement with the Member States and with what it hears here. The European Parliament clearly calls for a reduced rate on books and comparable conditions.

name: Michał BONI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Firstly, we need changes to VAT in order to adapt sales and the market to digital changes. Secondly, we need a review of this Mini One Stop Shop solution, which came into force earlier this year, to see how it actually affects the functioning of small businesses. Thirdly, we need simplification – the single electronic registration and payment mechanisms announced in the Digital Single Market Strategy are a good direction. Fourthly, of course, we need a uniform rate for books, both paper and electronic, but let us not forget the newspapers either. European newspapers will not survive the process of adapting to the digital world and competitiveness unless we treat them like books, that is, with this uniform VAT rate. Finally, the most important problem – you need to distinguish between service and product, or see them at the same time, so... (The President has received the speaker's vote.)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: For the following catch-the-eye procedure, we have more than twice as many requests as we have time available. I would therefore ask you to understand that I cannot take into account any speakers who have already spoken in a previous debate in the catch-the-eye procedure. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I welcome the fact that the proposed strategy calls for the same reduced VAT rates for online and offline works. It is certainly a mechanism that can facilitate access to European works, improve their circulation and stimulate the development of new services and platforms. The same reduced VAT rates can also help sell e-books, which in turn can enable smaller traders to survive in a market with big publications. The introduction of the same reduced VAT rates is the most positive move on the part of the European Commission. This element was one of the recommendations I made in my report on European film in the digital age, as this issue is crucial to facilitate the production, distribution, accessibility and attractiveness of European films. Thank you very much.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, it is incomprehensible that the digital book and the physical book will pay different VAT. If the work is the same, the taxes must be the same. It is high time we changed the rules to make both books pay the same VAT and the VAT rate reduced. Harmonisation is necessary and urgent, Commissioner. Europe has in its publishing industry a flagship, a leading global reference sector that must be protected according to its strategic character. We already know the dire impact that measures such as the rise of cultural VAT have had on my country. This respect must be reflected in the strategy for the digital single market, in order to boost a robust European content industry capable of generating jobs in times of economic crisis.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner. This debate is not a debate, it is a cry to the Commission. The old tax regulation on e-commerce benefited large companies, the giants, which constituted their registered office in countries with a very low VAT rate.  This new taxation must be seen as a whole and without harming the smallest companies, but - Commissioner - the digital single market is urgent and we cannot wait until 2016.  We can't forget about culture either. It's a cry here today. We're left behind. Common cultural taxation is key. A super-reduced cultural VAT is required for the whole of the European Union because a book is a book, Commissioner. We miss the opportunities between our fingers. Listen to us or we'll become your worst nightmare.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, everything I have heard here is half-measures. That is why I am calling for vat to be abolished and I want to analyse it and explain it. In theory, in principle, you should all know that it belongs to indirect and not direct taxes. Direct taxes are always at the expense of the people. But let's actually see what VAT is: value added tax. Added to what? When you buy a book, do you add value because you're the new reader? Think about that! When you consume a product, does that mean you add value to the new product? This is a tax to the detriment of consumers, to the detriment of the peoples, to the citizens and not to the detriment of capital. That's why I'm proposing to abolish it.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: – Mr President, in this debate we must start from the evidence that the general taxation in Europe on culture exhibits treatments so differentiated that they explicitly contradict the concept of fiscal fairness. I am also referring to what is happening in Spain, where there is an explicit 'tax punishment' on culture in all its forms, with one of the highest VAT rates in Europe — 21 %, except precisely for books in classical format, to which 4% applies. I share the criterion of equal tax treatment, with a reduced VAT rate, for books, whatever their format, in the name of the digital single market, but even more so, in the name of culture conceived as a general interest. It would be a difficult paradox to understand, let alone accept, for us to move forward on downside tax equality for all kinds of books and continue to be silent in the face of fiscal policies with serious and direct negative discrimination for culture as a whole, all while large digital operators enjoy, in fact, super-reduced taxation close to zero. This debate has become a cry in favour of urgent fiscal harmonisation in Europe with small and medium-sized enterprises in particular in place.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank you cordially for this fruitful debate. I would like to reflect on your question, Sophia, on why I am here and why Pierre Moscovici is not here. Pierre Moscovici is right now in the Bundestag in Berlin and this is the reason why I am here, but I think that both of those issues are directly related to the digital single market and this is the reason why I had to be here. Both those issues have a very long history but, as you said, there is a common understanding in the Commission that both of those issues are urgent issues. So let us talk about MOSS reform.  In 2004, our small and medium-sized companies were complaining because there was no fair competition. For big companies, for global players, it was so easy to remove their headquarters to countries where tax rates were at a very low level, and in this way our small and medium-sized companies were just out of the competition. That is why this reform was made. The decision was made in 2008 already. But, during those debates between 2004 and 2008, it was proposed by the Commission to set a threshold at quite a high level, under which our small and medium-sized companies did not have to declare their VAT revenue; and it was rejected by Member States.  This is one of those reasons why many people, many entrepreneurs, complained, and this is once again, according to my understanding, the reason why we had to propose to set this threshold for our micro-companies at quite a high level once again. I have stated it publicly many times already: according to my understanding, we proposed setting this threshold at the level of EUR 100 000, as it was during the years 2004 to 2008, and I think that our Member States were able to understand why this is so important for our small businesses. Talking about e-books, the decision was made in 2001 already not to allow those reduced VAT rates to be applied on e-services like e-books. Why is this question an urgent issue right now? It is because of this decision we had from the European Court of Justice just last year and we had to act. As President Jean-Claude Juncker stated already, we would like to propose to allow those reduced rates also to be used on e-books. We will get a report about the VAT MOSS this summer already, and on the basis of this report we can say when we will be able to make our proposals that change our legislation. So the Commission is acting already and I promise that I will do my utmost to make those proposals as soon as possible.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. – Currently the EU’s ambitions to create a common Digital Single Market are being largely obstructed by administrative hurdles such as different VAT rules across the Union and, more specifically, an unequal treatment of similar non—digital and digital services and goods. I hold the view that this not only distorts fair competition, discourages SMEs and e-commerce but also makes digital goods much more difficult and expensive for EU consumers to access. Hence, I think that there is a great practical need to have a uniform VAT regime in the EU. Moreover, I believe that the derogations and reduced VAT rates should be applied for digital books, journals and magazines as they are now already applied for the printed books (their physical counterparts) due to being classified as cultural goods. This would not only benefit producers and consumers but could have a positive impact on the development of digital information base, research and innovation. Finally, it must be noted that the digital sphere develops extremely fast, and if we want to keep up our competitiveness on the world scale there is an urgent need for action and the Commission should step up its efforts to address this issue.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: in writing. –  Proposals contained in the Commission’s Digital Single Market strategy to reduce the burden of new EU VAT rules for online firms are a very welcome development. The Commission has shown it is listening and wants to reduce the barriers the new rules have created for microbusinesses trying to sell their services across the EU However, as with any EU legislation we know it will take some time for these proposals to be debated and implemented. For the microbusinesses struggling to survive, there is no time to waste. Already there are clear issues with different levels of compliance and enforcement across EU Member States. The Commission and national governments must now look at what can be done immediately to help small businesses cope, including a temporary suspension of the rules while a solution is found.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. – In Germany, printed newspapers are subject to a reduced VAT rate of seven percent, while digital editions are taxed at 19 percent. This scheme is based on an EU directive from 1991, when online media were still barely used. It is therefore to be welcomed that the Commission's proposal to reduce red tape in the area of VAT for digital services, books and newspapers in the EU is to be welcomed. In this context, a reduced VAT rate for digital media is to be pushed, i.e. the VAT rate should be technology-neutral. Since January 2015, the country of destination principle has been in force in the EU Member States with regard to VAT, which is a major market value for digital books, films and music, but overall for all products sold online across borders. Small and medium-sized enterprises in particular are confronted with high barriers to entry in online trade, which is why only seven percent of SMEs sell across borders. Making the most of the opportunities offered by a digital market would save European consumers EUR 11.7 billion per year.

name: Fernando MAURA BARANDIARÁN
text: in writing. – The COURT of Justice of the EU establishes a difference between printed books, which are goods, and electronic books, which it considers to be a service. Therefore, a judgment of 5 March of that court has reminded France and Luxembourg that they cannot unilaterally impose reduced VAT on e-books, therefore in breach of the relevant directive and their obligation as Member States. However, as a reader, writer and politician, I think a book is a book. And it is regardless of its format, the material it is composed of and the way it is reproduced to reach the reader as long as it serves to carry out its essential cultural work: the dissemination of human knowledge. The ALDE Group requested that this matter be introduced to the agenda of the plenary session. Parliament has been calling on the Commission for years to rectify this error, this erquivocal absurdity which prevents Member States from truly harmonising VAT legislation on digital and printed books. This path must continue, not only in line with the demands of the European Digital Single Market, but also because the publishing industry in Europe is seriously at risk.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the one-minute speeches on important political issues (Article 163 of the CRP).

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Sándor Lamfalussy, who died last week and is known to many in this chamber as Alexander Lamfalussy and is considered the father of the euro, is rightly so. He was Hungarian, one of the great personalities that the Hungarian nation gave to the democratic world. Born in Kaposvár, Hungary, he emigrated from the Communist dictatorship in 1929. In 1953 he graduated from the Catholic University of Leuven with a degree in economics, after which he was the head of several major banks. From 1994 to 1997 he was the first president of emi, a European financial institution based in Frankfurt. Under his leadership, this Institute prepared the transition to the euro and edged the monetary policy of the EU Member States. He also held several medals, and 10 years ago, after my lecture at the Hungarian Academy of Sciences in Budapest, he came up to me, put his hand on my shoulder and said, "Hold on, son, yourselves over there, also in Slovakia!" Which meant that we, not Hungarians living in Hungary, were on the horizon of his moral vision.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Mr President, on Europe Day, together with a thousand PES activists from Romania, we started a campaign to demand our right to be in the Schengen area. It has been four years since the European Council concluded that Romania meets all the conditions.  Consequently, keeping Romania outside Schengen is an abuse. Basically, four years of discrimination against Romania are being fulfilled. It is the European Council and the Commission that allow this injustice. The Romanians I represent no longer want to hear how one or two states are blamed for the current gridlock. The European institutions have a responsibility to persuade reluctant Member States. We are talking about the EU's influence in the world, but we are not or do not want to persuade the Member States to respect a simple commitment. The European Commission applies a double standard: on the one hand it does not help Romania, but on the other hand it shows openness for renegotiating the treaties with another Member State - in this case the United Kingdom. Romanians are the Europeans with the highest degree of confidence in the European Union and it would be a shame if the European institutions did this. Romania is asking for Schengen. Romanians deserve in Schengen.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I would like to draw your attention once again to a very important issue, namely the Transatlantic Free Trade Agreement with the United States. This is because, perhaps somewhat unusually in this House, I want to talk about the rule of law and democracy. I would like to point out to you that you should work to ensure that this free trade agreement remains and will remain a free trade agreement, and that any attempt to negotiate into it that undermines the rule of law, restricts the rule of law at national level, which may undermine democracy and transfer decision-making powers that actually belong to the elected parliaments to supranational levels, will be prevented in this House, as far as possible.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: – I would like to speak briefly about one topic that we should have been talking about in this house as early as April of the month, but unfortunately we are not. Opposition politician Oleg Kalashnikov was murdered outside his house on April 15. I'm talking about Ukraine. On April 16, journalist Oleš Buzina. On April 17, Amnesty International published the following list of deaths under unusual circumstances, which they described as suicides. From January to mid-April this year, they are expected to commit suicide: Alexander Pekelenko, former regional governor, Stanislav Melnik, former member of parliament, Mikhail Čečetov, former Vice-President of the Party of Regions, Sergei Valter, Mayor of Melitopol, Alexei Kolesnik, former head of regional government in Kharkiv, Alexander Bordjuh, former police chief in Melitopol. Dear colleagues, if we are to believe the democracy of the Ukrainian authorities, they owe us the results of a thorough and objective investigation into these unusual deaths.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, negotiations on a solution to the Cyprus problem have resumed. We hope that this time there will be a positive outcome, that Turkish intransigence and the provocative refusal to recognise the sovereign rights of the Republic of Cyprus will be lifted. Our commitment to a solution, on the basis of relevant UN resolutions, international law and the relevant framework is a given. The previous convergences between the leaders of the two communities Christofias and Talat constitute an important acquis which must be exploited. We expect active support from the European Union in the fight for the reunification of Cyprus on the basis of a solution of a bi-social bi-community federation that respects international law, ensures the indivisibleness of our country and people, demilitarizes Cyprus, ends the anachronistic regime of guarantees, guarantees the human rights of all Cypriots. We call on you to exert your influence in Ankara so that it can finally make a meaningful and constructive contribution to the solution of the Cyprus problem.

name: Petr MACH
text: – Mr President, since November last year, a new voting system in the Council has been in place under the Treaty of Lisbon. In the Czech Republic, I was one of the loudest opponents of the Treaty of Lisbon. I asked at the time how it is possible that the size of Germany's voice is doubled and the size of the Czech voice is reduced by half? The politicians who defended the new voting system at the time told me that there was almost never a "hard vote" in the European Union, that consensus was always sought. And how is it today?  The European Commission is proposing a plan to redistribute refugees to member countries, and the Czech Republic, which does not agree with the distribution of people, can easily be over-voted. What is coming out of the European Union today is nothing more than a dictation, in such an incredible thing as dividing people. I will therefore call on the Czech Government to bring an action against the European Union for violations of the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by When I was a kid, I was taught that the Soviet Union was growing the fastest in the world, and I knew where America was developing, because that's where skyscrapers were created. This is a good indicator of economic development. Where are skyscrapers built today? Let's look at. In Africa, in Casablanca, Morocco, a skyscraper is being built 640 m. And in Europe? In Europe, the tallest skyscraper has half of that. There are ten skyscrapers higher than 300 m across Europe, 7 of them in Moscow, one in Istanbul, one in Frankfurt, one in London, which will soon leave the European Union. Under the occupation of the European Union, we are becoming an open-air museum, we are not developing, children are not being born, the economy is not growing, so I think the European Union must be destroyed. Therefore I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, around the world, 15 May is celebrated as International Family Day and the second Sunday in May is celebrated as Mother's Day. I deliberately commemorate them together, because women and mothers are the heart of the family. They often sacrifice their careers for the lives of their children, many women also try to combine the profession and childcare. Sadly, women in the European Union have on average 39% lower pensions and 15% lower salaries than men. One of the main reasons is that they are engaged in childcare. I am performing today to thank and encourage all these mothers. Motherhood is a great sacrifice, but above all a great privilege. This is despite the fact that today's society prefers mainly material values. Children are joy and they are our future. Those who realize this have perspective. I would also like the European Union's policy to clearly appreciate motherhood and parenthood. There is a lot of talk today about gender mainstreaming, and I think family mainstreaming should also become a permanent part of the impact assessment in order to make Europe favourable ... (The Speaker has removed the speaker's word.)

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Mr President, on 25 April there was a terrible earthquake in Nepal with more than 8,000 people killed, 17,000 injured and hundreds of thousands of homes destroyed. Last week a new tremor further increased the data of this horror.  The European Commission has acted with some speed with Commissioner Stylianides' presence on the ground and with a commitment to advance EUR 23 million from the international cooperation instrument to help the country. In any case, this is not enough, because in the coming months Nepal may suffer a hard monsoon that makes the conditions of this small great country even worse.  Among the missing are many Europeans, including Spaniards, of whom four Asturians, four people from my constituency: Sabino Fernández, Jesús Monteirín, Egidio García and Angel Hernández. I want from here to show my solidarity and the commitment of this House to their families and to the future of Nepal, which we have to help so much.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The Commission will soon cross a new red line. It will propose that the EU should also be given powers for direct corporate taxes for the first time. It wants to make the corporate tax base the same across the EU. The Member States should then only determine the tax rate. The EU does the rest. Unfortunately, there are also voices in my party who want to give the EU these powers. But these votes are also forming a new party and are about to leave the AfD. After all, the AfD is in favour of less EU, competition and anti-egalitarianism – also and especially in tax law, in all areas of tax law, including the tax base. I make it clear that the EU must not be given competence in the area of direct taxation. This is national competence. That is the competence of the Member States. And that must remain the same!

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Mr President, honourable Members, I take the floor in the one-minute speech procedure with the clear knowledge that only two days later there is a deliberate debate on the Republic of Macedonia. Recently, the Bulgarian Liberal Party – DPS, through its President expressed its position on the conflict in Kumanovo. Undoubtedly, conflict can be interpreted by many countries, but it should remind us, most importantly, that the transition from totalitarianism to democratic civil society in the Balkans has been marked by bloody ethnic conflicts due to nationalist ideologies that have long displaced civil causes. The only country in the Balkans that managed to make a peaceful bloodless transition was my homeland, the Republic of Bulgaria. Thanks to its unique ethnic model – the model of tolerance. Dear Colleagues, the only way that frozen conflicts in the Western Balkans will not be provoked by aggression is a balanced European approach. In this sense, we categorically do not accept jean-Claude Juncker's five-year refusal to expand, which already has a severe negative psychological effect. We should not absolate the criterion that the parties have decided in advance on all their bilateral ... ... (The President took away the speaker's word)

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: – Mr President, the Strasbourg Court has already delivered seven judgments condemning the Spanish State for not investigating allegations of torture by Basque citizens. But, again, seven young Basques who had reported being tortured by Spanish security forces while incommunicado are sentenced to six years in prison by the Audiencia Nacional for political activity.  To denounce all this and tuck in three young men against whom he still weighed a warrant, hundreds of people were peacefully concentrated in Vitoria-Gasteiz yesterday. Unfortunately, the police brutally beat dozens of young people again to arrest these three people. Dozens of people are injured and two of them were knocked unconscious by police action. It is time to overcome these situations, to banish political trials in exceptional courts forever and to recover civil and political rights for all people in my country, Euskal Herria.

name: Karima DELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, last Wednesday Jean-Claude Juncker presented his programme for the European Union's migration policy. He became a minimum awareness of reality by proposing that Member States accept each one a distribution of refugees according to objective criteria, in short, to show a minimum of European solidarity. But, obviously, the bar was too high for some European leaders, including French Prime Minister Manuel Valls, who said at the weekend that he was against the quotas allocated to each country.  However, it has been said for weeks and has been repeated, as migrants die in the Mediterranean, the answer to this scourge will be European or not. When the European Commission finally takes a first step, France does not take its responsibilities and adopts, like Great Britain, Poland and Hungary, a totally harmful attitude.  Today, France, the country of human rights, is not there. She must not be afraid of populists and the extreme right. We cannot accept the side of the Europhobes. So, Mr Heads of State, we cannot say constantly: "It is Europe's fault" and, at the same time, refuse to listen to it when it is there.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: Mr President, we are witnessing a phenomenon in France linked to negotiations with the United States and the transatlantic market. We know the development of factory farms, with thousands of animals, either for milk or for meat. We had the farm of 1,000 cows in the Somme, that of the 1,000 calves slaughtered hallal in Creuse, the farm of 2,000 animals in Touraine, 20,000 hens in Picardy, 12,000 pigs in Gironde, etc. It is in fact the U.S. model of feed lots that spreads even before the signing of the treaty, which does not bode well after the signing of the treaty. You should also be concerned that people are actually hostile to these factory farms because they are concerned about the farming methods of these animals and the products used. Our compatriots, and many farmers for that matter, have indeed pushed the supermarket to boycott the milk of this farm called 1,000 cows. Once again, people are organizing against the harmful effects of your policies. As I said before, producers are also organizing to combat the pressure of mass distribution.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. President, the problem of depopulation of rural areas is a pronounced problem in the Member States of the southeast of the European Union, including in the Republic of Croatia from which I come. Keeping young people in the countryside, engaging and engaging them in agricultural activities are crucial to preventing these negative developments in order to maintain or raise the quality of life with the required level of services in rural areas to a higher level.  Given that Croatian 'young farmers' and 'farmers just starting agricultural activity' did not use funding from the EU budget on these grounds under bps or single payment schemes before Croatia's accession to the EU, I consider the provision of the period of five years from the establishment of the holding before the first application for them to be submitted. I call on the Commission to recognise and eliminate this discrimination against Croatian young farmers and to take the necessary actions to adequately ensure equal rights for Croatian young farmers and to prevent discrimination against young farmers in other Member States.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: – Mr President, Parliament's Committee on Foreign Affairs adopted on 10 May 2015 a proposal to revise the European Union's strategy towards Russia, which is accused of occupying the Crimea region and supporting separatists in eastern Ukraine. I believe that the drafting of this document must take particular account of the fact that Romania and Poland are the main European Union countries affected by the Ukrainian crisis. Geographically, whether we like it or not, the war is on the border of the European Union, and Romania has shown that it is united and responsible by following the positions expressed by the European Union and the US, even if, from an economic point of view, it is directly affected by the perpetuation of this conflict. The crisis can have much more significant repercussions in the future, through pressure on energy prices, but also through the fact that Russia and Ukraine are the main trade gates of the European Union and Romania to the Eastern markets. , within the European Union, the other Member States must show their solidarity, also taking into account the interests of the Romanian nation, and discuss the revision of the strategy with balance. It is time to show solidarity, because we need a united Europe of all nations.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the credit suffocation towards my country, Greece, imposed by the loan lenders, led by Mario Draghi and his company at the European Central Bank, has dominated the last three months. The aim of the lenders is to enforce the harsh memorial policy of austerity, the reduction of wages and pensions and the sale of public property instead of a lentil plate. However, instead of putting its hands on the reserves of insurance funds and municipalities, the Greek Government's financial staff must immediately use Article 7 of Regulation No 3603/1993, which exceptionally allows the monetary financing of governments by their national central banks and the ECB, in order to fulfil their obligations to the International Monetary Fund. Austria has already received loans from its Central Bank at least three times in recent years, with the blessing of the ECB, to repay its obligations to the International Monetary Fund. Direct loan of Greece, from the Bank of Greece for the repayment of the IMF, here and now!

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Mr President, there is no politics or democracy without humanistic thought and values. National states, right now, are too weak to defend themselves against a global crisis that is not only economic, but also political and shared convictions.  My party believes that European citizenship should be part of the educational curriculums in every country of the European Union, and this is one of our great commitments. And we understand this as a way of dealing with populismos, forms of political pathologies, fanaticism, as an antidote to the extension of terrorist radicalism of jihadists and also against the lies of friends of impunity in the end-of-terrorism scenarios, such as in my country, in the Basque Country.  Democratic citizenship is the intellectual antidote to any barbarization of our society. As important as smart borders, such as security policy, is a positive extension of our democracy. As I say, I believe so, Mr. President.

name: Max ANDERSSON
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Now, after the British elections, most of the evidence suggests that the country will ask for a renegotiation and a referendum on EU membership. It is a symptom of the fact that europe has serious democratic problems, which we must take seriously. Marginal changes are not enough – we need a proper renegotiation of the Treaty. There is much that can be improved. We need decentralisation. We need to make better use of the EU budget. We need to strengthen the role of national parliaments in the decision-making process. All countries should have the right not to participate in EMU. Those countries that need to leave the euro zone should be given the right and help to do so. Recent years clearly show that the euro zone needs an emergency exit. What we need now is not a negotiation to make Europe better for a Member State. What we need now is a negotiation to make Europe better for everyone.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – The events in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, the events in Kosovo, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina highlight how dangerous the Western Balkans area is. Following the enlargement process, which results in 110 million more people in the European Union, the European Union has shown signs of fatigue, so this uncertainty that people in the Western Balkans are receiving, with about 20 million of them wanting to come to the European Union, is uncertain.  I therefore think that we, in the European Parliament, in the European Commission, should once again have a thorough debate about whether this enlargement process really has so much to delay. I also firmly believe that the dispute around the name of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia must be resolved and that pre-accession assistance must be strengthened, because if these development differences increase from year to year, we will continue to deal with the unlovable events in this part of Europe.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: – Thank you very much. Deindustrialisation is the main cause of unemployment in the Union as a result of the relocation of low-value-added production to third countries. In the former Eastern Bloc, however, hostile takeovers were the reason for this as a result of the hasty, scandalous privatization of state industry. Many modern plants with design offices, research centers were acquired and then international corporations liquidated them, getting rid of competition. Reindustrialisation Polish therefore requires other, more comprehensive solutions. However, the relativism of the share of industry in Polish GDP by current decision-makers is not encouraging. They downplay two-and-a-half million emigration and one and a half million unemployment. Only manufacturing potential, the share of which Polish in GDP would correspond to the average GDP of the Union in 2020, is the only real opportunity for my country by using EU funds to create the jobs needed for small and medium-sized enterprises. Thank you.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Free elections are not just about counting votes fairly. Free elections are, above all, a fair election campaign. The same applies – perhaps even more so – to the referendum. That is why we need to talk about the worrying signals that are coming to us three days before the Irish referendum – the signals about the freedom of this referendum. Contrary to Irish law, namely supreme court rulings, there is no question of respecting the equality of the parties in the referendum debate. Publicly funded political parties are threatening to exclude their members from the party against homosexual rewinds. In the public media, not to mention the private media, only one party dominates – the one that supports the overturning of the current law. There have been very serious cases of employers urging their employees to engage on the homosexual side in this referendum. What does all this have to do with democracy?

name: Seán KELLY
text: - The Uachtaráin, roghnaíodh mé le déanaí mar rapóirtéir air an gCoiste a Thionscal, a Thaighde agus a Fhuinneamh (ITRE) air athrú aeráide agus tá súil agam go n-éireoidh linn idirbheartaíocht a fháil i bPáras ag deireadh naa blina seo.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in Brianza, in the vimercatese specifically, there is a production district where most high-tech companies are concentrated, a potential spearhead of our industry and, on the contrary, for years overwhelmed by the crisis. This territory has developed an excellent contamination between small companies and large multinationals, but they are facing the crisis through relocation actions with decisions taken at the table without a restructuring project. These decisions are costing Italy and Europe a wealth in terms of know-how and technology. This is not a national issue but a deeply European one, especially at a time of investment in a new strategy for the digital single market.  We therefore also need a European perspective in the creation of a liaison structure that can encourage dialogue between the large companies and the individual professionals of different Member States who have been operating in these sectors for years and which represent our greatest opportunity for development.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – It seems to me right to remember at this meeting that, 100 years ago, on 23 May, the Soška Front was launched on Slovenian soil in the context of the 1st World War.  In three years, it has taken over 300,000 lives of soldiers from many European nations, leaving behind many civilian casualties. The battle gas was also used for the first time on the Isaic Front. I am pleased that the paths of peace are taking place in the area of the then front, and the Museum of Kobarid reminds us of our political responsibility by showing the tragedy of those times.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Mr President, with the debate on TTIP picking up across the Atlantic, it is becoming clear that both the EU and the US executives have severely misjudged the public mood on Investor-State Dispute Settlement or ISDS. ISDS has proved to be an obstacle for Congress to support TTIP. In this House, a large and growing number of MEPs are conditioning their support for the continuing negotiations on the full rejection of ISDS. EU citizens are not prepared to compromise on democracy and they will not accept us compromising on ISDS either. Sadly, the Commission remains intransigent in its defence of multinationals’ privileges when it should be the champion of citizens, justice and fairness. ISDS is like a cancer and the Commission is letting it infect the whole of TTIP. This undermines TTIP’s potential to open up trade and set the high global standards that our companies and our workers urgently need.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: That concludes this item.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of Piernicola Pedicini's report on safe healthcare in Europe: improving patient safety and curbing antimicrobial resistance (2014/2207(INI)) (A8-0142/2015).

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow we will be voting on an own-initiative report by the European Parliament which aims to increase patient safety in health care and the objective of combating with all possible energy the great threat posed by the growth of resistance to antimicrobial agents.  If we refer to patient safety, the ECDC states that around 10 % of those admitted to hospital suffer damage or adverse events that must be avoided.  We have tried to identify the causes of all this and, consequently, to take the most appropriate action to prevent medical errors and the risk of hospital infections.  I would therefore like to mention some of the most important points: the elimination of political interference in the appointments of managers and health professionals, including the practice of the Spoil System, first of all, and the abolition of economic austerity measures, because we cannot endorse those measures that have an impact on patient safety, such as the reduction of medical staff or staff specialising in hygiene.  If we are talking about the increase in antimicrobial resistance, we must remember that 25 000 EU citizens die each year as a result of this cause, and the figures are set to soar, both in terms of human lives and in terms of economic costs. It should also be remembered that an increasing number of animals are infected with antimicrobial resistant bacteria and that this poses a risk in the consumption of animal meat. I will cite just a few of these measures: the importance of a commitment by the pharmaceutical industry to a genuine search for new antimicrobial drugs and at the same time the openness to research into new natural methods of combating pharmacoresistance; the ban on online sales; the elimination of prophylactic use and the strong limitation of metaphylactic use in the veterinary sector. I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs from all the political groups who have contributed constructively to the drafting of this own-initiative report and, finally, I am proud to be able to point out that this report also represents a first real application of democracy directed at the European Parliament, because it has involved some citizens who have proposed their amendments online, which were then voted on and included in the final text that you will be voting on tomorrow. Thank you all for your contribution.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I believe that this report is of particular importance to all of us. In sTOA – that is the European Parliament's Scientific and Technology Options Assessment – we have actually made it very clear that, on the one hand, antibiotic resistance is a real threat and, on the other hand, we have not yet achieved the right results with brain research. That is why I believe that in future, including in the European Parliament, we should look at the Perfect Life programme with STOA even more intensively in this area.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – (– Mr President), improving patient safety and combating microbial antibiotic resistance must be a strong objective of public health policies. Three brief notes on this issue. First, the attack on public health systems aggravates and makes it difficult to solve these problems. It is within the framework of universal and free quality health services, with qualified professionals, with rights and in sufficient numbers, that a whole range of preventive practices and procedures can be best adopted, both at the level of primary and hospital health care. This is just the opposite of what's been done in the last few years. The situation has worsened and greatly and the European Union has heavy responsibilities. Secondly, the consequences of the indiscriminate use of antibiotics in livestock must be fully understood and combated, which requires a profound change in the existing production models and the associated agricultural and commercial policies. Thirdly, it is crucial to step up research and development efforts for new drugs and to do so by disputing the primacy of multinational drugs in this area and strengthening public capacities.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – In this House, we regularly deal with problems caused by the overuse of antibiotics. However, I would like to draw attention to that part of my colleague Pedicini's report, which talks about the increased incidence of infections in health facilities, which is due to cuts in cleaning expenditure. Fewer cleaning staff, especially in hospitals, are directly reflected in the reduction in patient safety. Any compromise that the hospital management makes in the area of cleanliness and hygiene directly results in an increase in the number of microbial infections. The result is unnecessary complications often with serious consequences for the health and life of the patient. Solving these complications is much more expensive than the price to ensure cleanliness and hygiene at the highest level.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Mr President, an important report on two dangers to health systems in the European Union. Antimicrobial resistance is a growing threat because it interferes with effective prevention and treatment of a wide range of infections. Patient safety is another extremely important theme and it is very worrying that between 8 and 12 per cent of European patients fall victim to healthcare-related adverse effects when they are in hospitals. I plead for the continuous training of all medical personnel, I plead to ensure that medical personnel inform patients about the use, in addition to indications, of medicines. We also need to define, all Member States, minimum patient safety standards in the European Union. I also believe that we need to use all the opportunities at our disposal to discover new, more effective antibiotics.

text: – A Uachtaráin, i mo theanga tá seanfhocal ann a deir “Is fearr an tsláinte ná na táinte”. Is fíor sin mar muna mbíonn an tsláinte agat is deacair taitneamh a bhaint as an saol. name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by thanking the rapporteur Mr Pedicini and by congratulating the members of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) on their excellent work.  On patient safety, I am glad to see that the report, while recognising the progress made so far, seeks to go further and do more for the safety of citizens. I also welcome the call for enhanced cooperation with stakeholders in the interests of a coordinated, comprehensive and sustainable EU approach to patient safety. This call is in line with the Council Conclusions on patient safety and quality of care adopted on 1 December 2014 under the Italian Presidency. The proposed report also rightly underlines the importance of having sufficient health professionals, including in hospital settings, with the right skills and up-to-date knowledge.  Turning to antimicrobial resistance (AMR), I would like to underline how important it is that antibiotics be dispensed only under prescription, and that treatment with antibiotics is based on proper diagnosis. AMR knows no borders and can spread between humans, animals, the environment and food. The cost to human and animal health is high, as is the direct impact on our economies. All this points to the urgent need for coordinated efforts to combat AMR. For many years, this issue has been a priority for the Commission. In 2011, we launched the five-year Action Plan based on the ‘One Healthʼ concept, involving all sectors and aspects of antimicrobial resistance.  Three and a half years later, we can be proud that important progress has been made in Europe and that the Action Plan has contributed to increasing international awareness about this serious worldwide public health concern. I am confident that together – Parliament, the Member States, the Commission and civil society – we can succeed in improving further patient safety and in stepping up the fight against antimicrobial resistance.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday 19 May. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Pavel POC
text: in writing. – Although Parliament is currently discussing a revision of EU veterinary legislation, the problem of antimicrobial resistance is not given sufficient attention in the Commission's proposals. This own-initiative report shows that Parliament intends to address this area in much more detail. I welcome the initiatives and actions taken by Member States, animal health experts and animal owners to ensure responsible antibiotic use and the limited use of antibiotics in animal husbandry. It is essential to promote responsible use of all antimicrobials in veterinary medicine and, moreover, particular attention should be paid to those substances that are crucial in human medicine, such as fluorochinolones and cephalosporins of the third and fourth generation. National strategies or action plans to combat antimicrobial resistance need to be developed and implemented. The implementation of national guidelines on the treatment of animals with antimicrobials should ensure responsible use of antimicrobials based on specific recommendations and conditions in the Member States concerned and should allow them sufficient flexibility. The application of preventive animal health policies aimed at improving the health status and reducing the need to use antimicrobials in breeding is also key. It is equally necessary to define the obligations of veterinarians with regard to health care and decision-making on the use of antimicrobials and to provide ongoing training for animal health professionals and animal owners.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. – In the context of quality healthcare, we must stress that patient safety is also closely linked to labour shortages. Unfortunately, little has been said about this in the report. The shortage of health workers in the European Union is growing. The Commission estimates that by 2020 around 1 million health workers will be missing from healthcare systems in Europe. The reasons are complex, including an increase in the average age of workers, a lack of supplies and an increase in the needs of an ageing society for care. Hungary, the real problem for The European Union and several other new Member States is the exodus of health workers. In Europe, we are witnessing a reverse labour dumping: the old Member States are promising to attract specialists, nurses and social workers from the new Member States abroad, promising salaries of 5-10 times, causing serious security of supply problems in the countries concerned. As it is not expected that the Member States most affected by the exodus will be able to raise the salaries of health workers to a similar level in a short period of time, it is essential that the European Commission takes priority in addressing the problem. It is not enough to draw up EU action plans and studies, concrete assistance and European solidarity are needed to remedy the worsening situation.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of Philippe De Backer's report on "Opportunities for Green Growth of SMEs" (2014/2209(INI)) (A8-0135/2015).

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: Rapporteur. I am nevertheless very pleased to be able to give a brief introduction to the European Parliament's initiative report on green growth opportunities for SMEs at this late hour. First of all, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and also the secretariat of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy for their good cooperation.  Green growth is about exploiting the opportunities that help make the transition to a more sustainable economy. It is very simple to me: if we all continue to consume as we do today, we will need 40% more water and energy in the next 20 years. At that rate, we also need three times more natural resources by 2050. It is therefore important that we let a mind shift take place. We need to make the transition to a more sustainable, more efficient, but also low-carbon economy. We must also ensure that our policies create the right conditions so that companies can innovate, invest and remain competitive.  At present, the world market for environmental goods and services accounts for around EUR 1000 billion per year. It is estimated that this could double or even triple by 2020, and the green economy continued to grow during the economic crisis. Europe is showing leadership here in terms of recycling and energy efficiency, and the stakes are therefore on how we can strengthen and maintain that leadership. That is also the use of my report. At the same time, it sums up the opportunities offered by the green economy, but on the other hand the report highlights a number of problems that SMEs face if they want to invest and go along with the story of the green economy and the circular economy.  Because I have been able to speak to a lot of companies and entrepreneurs personally and a number of things always came back. The search for good funding, the red tape they face, but also the knowledge needed to invest in this domain. It is therefore imperative that business leaders become more familiar with alternative ways of financing, such as venture capital, but also crowdfunding. We need to get rid of the idea that our economy can only be financed by debt and by banks.  It's also about knowledge management. It is also about the fact that business leaders need to be given knowledge and access to knowledge in order to innovate, but also that the right information flows to the field. Entrepreneurs need to keep up to date with new technological developments, and the role of sector federations in this is particularly important. They can really guide their members and help them get to the latest technology, the latest financing opportunities and also share knowledge with each other.  Research and development, innovation must continue to be stimulated in order to remain the market leader, but also to find new applications in the green economy. It is not so much a question of granting additional subsidies, because only 9% of new companies use subsidies, but it is important to look at how we can make a good combination of available financial resources and the innovation that is sought.  If I look at the Belgian situation, it is also about us adapting the legislation. 65% of European legislation was made at a time when the Internet was not a significant factor, for example, so we must also ensure that our legislation is future-proofed. These disruptive ideas need a framework that allows development, which pushes development further than it does today.  We must also dare to look at ourselves. We must also dare to look at how we can make our legislation more transparent, clearer, also lighter, sometimes to give new opportunities, to give new businesses every opportunity to remain competitive. This will ensure the return of growth in Europe. This will create new jobs and will ultimately lead to a greater well-being of our citizens.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would also like to congratulate Mr De Backer, because it is, of course, precisely this report that is of particular importance for our future in Europe.  Green growth means sustainable growth, and I believe that the green sector will, of course, have a large market ahead of it in the future, particularly at international level. That is why it is important that we take care, especially in the case of small and medium-sized enterprises, that they are able to exercise the export conditions accordingly. They need support here. After all, it is also a question of new business models moving in and thus creating completely new opportunities worldwide, especially via the Internet. That is why we believe that young dynamic start-ups – and this is very good news in the report – will be an opportunity in the future to get Europe's young people back to work.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, we are talking about green growth, we are talking about how to support small and medium-sized enterprises. But there can be no support for small and medium-sized enterprises when we have a tax raid. I should therefore like to inform you that at the moment, the troika in Greece is demanding an increase in VAT. There should be an increase in VAT in the Aegean islands now, at a time when we have the tourist season, at a time when we expect there to be a recovery in the economy, while we expect tourism to create jobs. So Greece's heavy industry, tourism, cannot be hit by the increase in VAT. You understand that we will have the opposite effect: increasing VAT in a country that is really poor and has one and a half million unemployed will lead to greater poverty. That is why we must have zero VAT on basic foodstuffs in order for the Greek people to survive. Do not have increased VAT on small and medium-sized enterprises in order to develop the Greek economy.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, environmental protection, the efficient and sustainable use of resources, re-use, recycling and other sustainable development objectives are undoubtedly opportunities for the development of a wide range of small and medium-sized enterprises. But here we must warn: the market for environmental goods and services to which this report alludes cannot justify or legitimise old or new forms of private appropriation of nature and its resources. Nor can it dismiss or exempt public institutions from the responsibilities and tasks they must have in these areas. As for the blockages that SMEs are in, such as the costs of some production factors, credit, for example, should be discussed. The need for public control of strategic sectors of the economy is reinforced, breaking with the prevailing oligopoly structure in several of these sectors and stifling SMEs.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – We talk about medium and small enterprises in virtually every plenary session, and there are many predictions about making it easier for SMEs to access business, to actually improve their situation, but it seems that it is actually increasingly staying at the theoretical level. It is clear that the Majority task must also be carried out by the Member States, but at least if we look at the area of recycling and waste and the circular economy, which is not currently a priority for the Commission, it must be said that currently 60% of all waste is currently not recycled, composted or reused, which is a great opportunity for SMEs.  And much more, including in the report, thank you, Mr Rapporteur, is written about this, but I would like to add one more thing: in order to really move forward, it is also necessary to amend and adapt the legislation.  One of these important legal frameworks for better functioning and accessibility for SMEs is the area of public procurement.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: – It must be acknowledged that small and medium-sized enterprises already provide services that contribute to green-sustainable economic growth. However, often due to a lack of resources, they operate in a defined area and their ideas, products and services are known only to a limited number of people. As a result, small businesses often invest a lot of time and resources in reinstalting the bicycle. I therefore support the ideas set out in the report that not only support these enterprises and facilitate the use of their support, but it is necessary to develop European networks of small businesses. Both informal networks and the establishment of a European Resource Efficiency Competence Centre should help businesses to exchange good practices and to ensure resource efficiency. We also need to create a simple consumer information system to promote the development of a green and sustainable economy. By allowing the consumer to make choices, we will not only support a sustainable business, but will also change people's daily habits and attitudes towards the environment, the harm it causes.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am really glad to see the European Parliament’s interest in fostering green growth opportunities for SMEs. I really want to congratulate Mr De Backer on this report because the Green Action Plan is at the heart of the Commission’s priorities – the transformation of EU industry through innovation and modernisation with the involvement of SMEs. Resource efficiency is one of the drivers for industrial transformation with positive effects on the environment. Europe has much to gain, as has already been said: up to EUR 630 billion per year in resource savings.  Our starting point is good. Eco-industry and eco-innovation currently supply one third of the global market for green technologies. But let me point to a few issues also indicated in the report. One point is that 75% of SMEs in the EU have seen an increase in their costs of materials in the past five years.  My second point is that, in manufacturing SMEs, raw materials – and this is really important – represent on average 40% of total costs, with energy and water pushing this up to 50%. This compares, for example, to a share of 20% for labour costs.  The third point is that reducing energy consumption is a priority for 80% of medium-sized companies. Finally – and this point was also made by Mr Šoltes – SMEs find it difficult to get value from their waste. We are very pleased to see that the rapporteur and the Commission have identified similar challenges and proposed similar actions, specifically in the areas of improving financing, facilitating innovation and strengthening cross-sectoral collaboration and knowledge transfer, in particular to clusters. On access to finance, which is a key priority for the Commission, we will work to ensure complementarity between different EU sources. The Commission is currently working on an ambitious package to pave the way towards a circular economy. The Green Action Plan for SMEs is intended to enable SMEs to turn this challenge into real business opportunities. We welcome your support for the forthcoming European Resource Efficiency Excellence Centre, which will provide information and advice on the performance and cost-effectiveness of different resource-efficient options, directly and through partners to SMEs. We want to reach as many SMEs as possible. Knowledge sharing among the Centre, the renewed Enterprise Europe Network and European clusters will be instrumental in this. Clusters are catalysts for SME cooperation and, by putting SMEs at the centre of such collaboration in our call under the Horizon 2020 programme, clusters can contribute to Europe’s industrial transformation in a more resource-efficient economy. Once again I would like to thank you very much for the valuable input of your Assembly on this topic. I really look forward to continuing our dialogue in the future for the benefit of all European SMEs.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday 19 May. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - Growth in the European Union and reindustrialisation are increasingly based on so-called green solutions and green approaches to business. In this context, the key driver of economic and sustainable growth is SMEs, which make up more than 98% of European businesses and which are important to enable them to use environmental challenges to make the most of the economic opportunities they have.  Furthermore, it has been established that, still, mainly highly developed SMEs are those that create green innovation, but other companies also need to adapt to environmental regulations. In order to achieve such a result, it is necessary to start from deregulation. In particular, it is necessary for Member States, through the revision of existing legislation and by reducing over-regulation, to remove barriers to the internal market. On the other hand, it is also essential that the European Commission focuses its efforts towards innovation-friendly legislation. Such adjustments and changes must of course be accompanied by various measures and supports, such as for easier start-ups, and concrete and realistic funding and lending models in order to actually deliver and fully implement green initiatives.  Therefore, I support the strengthening of green growth and the circular economy, as they enable the development of opportunities related to various sectors, in particular those of renewable energy sources.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. – The European Parliament's resolution on green growth opportunities for SMEs is a step towards strengthening the Small Business Act strategy, which allows the EU to enable SMEs to turn environmental challenges into opportunities. Since 2008, the EU has started to create a legislative framework to ensure that micro-enterprises and SMEs take advantage of the opportunities offered by the Single Market and promote qualifications and innovations in SMEs.  I believe that the Commission's Green Action Plan for SMEs, which underpins the resolution voted on today, provides a clear direction in which the EU intends to help SMEs move to a green and circular economy. The sectors concerned are: renewable energy, resource efficiency, waste management, emission reduction and recycling. This initiative presents a number of concrete actions: supporting SMEs to use the commercial potential of eco-innovation (COSME Programme), cross-sectoral collaboration (efficiency of the workforce in the circular economy: repairs, redevelopments and recycling), the establishment of the European Centre of Excellence which will provide advice and assistance to SMEs, including on European programmes.  I stress the importance of better coordination between the financial instruments in the EU budget, within the framework of the European Structural and Investment Funds, the Green Innovation Fund, the Employment Programme and the LIFE Programme.
